The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,363 texts created during Phase 1 of the project have been released into the public domain as of 1 January 2015. Anyone can now take and use these texts for their own purposes, but we respectfully request that due credit and attribution is given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).

div.p: THE PICTURE OF Quakerism Drawn to the Life. In Two Parts.

The First, Shewing the Vanity of the Quakers pretence of their being the one, only Catholick Church of Christ; and that the Apostolick Order thereof; is Re-established amongst them; and them only; Also shewing, That Legal Punishment is not Persecution, whereby the Christian Magistrates of the English Government, are cleared from the odious scandal of Persecution; charged on them by the Quakers.
The Second, Containing, a brief History of the Rise, Growth, and Progress of Quakerism; being a modest Correction of the General History of the Quakers wrot in Holland by Gerrard Croese.
By Francis Bugg, Sen.
div.q: Behold, I will make them of the Synagogue of Satan, which say they are Jews and are not; but do lye: Behold, I will make them to come and worship before thy feet; and to know that I have loved thee, Rev. 3.9.
div.p: London, Printed for, and are to be sold by W. Kett ••• y at the Bishop's-Head in St. Paul's Church-yard, and W. Rogers at the Sun in Fleet-street, 1697.

div.head: To the Right Reverend the Bishops of the Church of England.
div.p:
I Here present to Your Lordships view, Two small Tracts; the one shewing the Quakers presumptuous Claim, to the Title of being themselves the only True Catholick Church of Christ, the Elect People of God, and Church of the first Born; and that the Apostolical Order of the Church of Christ is Re-established amongst them; and them only, which whether so or no, let the World judge, when they have heard, and come more and more to know their Tenents, Principles, and Practises,
which are now every day more and more exposed; and in order to a farther discovery of their pernitious Errors, I have (according to my small Tallent) cast in my Mite; which I hope will not be unacceptable to Your Lordships, who are set as Overseers of the Church; and cannot but be affected with sorrow, when you see so many, (and some of them well meaning Souls) incorporate themselves into the Communion of this Erronious Sect; and indeed the most dangerous, because the most prevailing: But, I hope, they are at the heighth, and their Folly is so manifest, and their Errors are so discover'd; that as St. Paul writing to Timothy said, that as Jannes and Jambres withstood Moses; so did many in his days hold dangerous Errors; and so
willfully persisted in them that they resisted the Truth; who were Men of corrupt minds, and not only so, but Reprobates concerning the Faith of our Lord Jesus Christ: But St. Paul comforts himself, and his Son Timothy (to whom he had given divers things in charge) saying, They shall proceed no further, for their Folly shall be made manifest to all Men: And I am perswaded, that both the Folly and Danger of this erroneous Sect will be so manifest in a little time, that the gangrene of their Heresie shall prevail no further, which God of his mercy grant for Christ's sake. Amen.

The second Tract mentioned, which I now call the second Part, is a Correction of the late General History of the Quakers, &c. Wrot by Mr. Croese, wherein he has been
very partial in many things, which I charitably suppose might be done, partly for want of a thorow knowledge of their Tenets, and partly thorow wrong Information; and thereby have both reflected upon the Government, and Church of England, to the advantage of that willingly ignorant and pernicious Sect of the Quakers; and which I have endeavoured to set right according to that knowledge I have of that People: Their Books, their Principles, their Practices, and way and manner of their Church-Government which they pretend to be Apostolical.

My Lords, I have not leisure to trace them in all their by-pathes, from the very beginning of their rise, and to shew how they branched forth from the Seeds of the Ranters,
Levellers, and other Latitudinarians; nor do I certainly know that the Jesuits had a hand in their forming, but will say with my Lord of Worcester, in his Book Entituled, A Discourse concerning the Idolatry of the Church of Rome, &c. p. 282. viz. Any one who compares them (i. e. Jesuits and Quakers) would imagine the Life of Ignatius had been their great Exampler. I know not whether any of that innocent Order of Jesuits had any hand in forming this new Society (i. e. Quakers) amongst us, as has been frequently suggested; but if one may guess the Father by the Child's likeness, Ignatius Loyola, the Founder of the Jesuits, was at least the Grand-Father of the Quakers, &c. To which let me add an Abstract of a Letter from
the Right Reverend, J. Bramhall, Bishop of Derry, aftewardr Primate of Ireland, to the Most Revered James Usher Archbishop of Armagh, July 20. 1654. viz. I thank God I do take my Pilgrimage patiently; yet I cannot but condole the change of the Church and State of England; and more in my Pilgrimage than ever, because I dare not witness and declare to that stray'd Flock of our Brethren in England, who have misled them, and who they are that feed them. But, that your Lordship may be more sensible of the Churches Calamities, and of the danger she is in of being ruined, if God be not merciful unto her, I have sent you a part of my Discoveries (i. e.) That in the year 1646. by Order from Rome above 100 of the Romish
Clergy were sent into England, consisting of English, Scotch, and Irish, who had been Educated in France, Italy, Germany, and Spain, in each of those Romish Nurseries. These Scholars were taught several handicraft Traids and Callings, as their ingenuities were most bending, besides their Orders and Functions of that Church. They have many yet at Paris a fitting up to send over, who twice in the Week oppose one the other; when the Romish Orders do thus Argue pro and con, there is appointed one of the learned of those Convents; and to take Notes as he find their Fancies, for This, That, and the other Opinion, new Tenents; so accordingly they be to act, and to exercise their Wits; accordingly upon their permission, when they
be sent abroad, they enter their Names in the Convent Registry; also their Licences if a Franciscan, if a Dominican or Jesuit; and for assurance of their constancy to their several Orders, they are to give monthly Intelligence to the Fraternities of all Affairs where-ever they be dispersed: So that, the English abroad know News better than you at home: All which is left to every Man to judge as he finds reason to do. And being loath to detain your Lordships, I beg leave to subscribe my self,

closer.signed: Your most Humble and most Obedient Son and Servant, Francis Bugg, Senior.

div.head: The Picture of Quakerism.
CHAP. I.
Shewing the Quakers Pride and Self-exaltation, in pretending to be the only True Catholick Church of Christ: And that the True Apostolical Order thereof is re-established amongst them only.
div.p:
HAving in my former Books, particularly my second Summary, &c. p. 8. set forth the Quakers Judgment and Opinion of all the Protestant Churches to be no Churches of Christ; but the Synagogue of Satan; and their Ministers a false Ministry: Even All that Baptize Children with Water, All that Preach Christ without, as he is in Heaven above at God's right Hand; All that Preach out of the Scriptures; All that tell People of a Sacrament, and that it is God's Ordinance; All that pay Tythes or receive Tythes: In a word, All Ministers, (not Quakers) are, say they, false Ministers; and as such they are Conjurers, Thieves and Robbers, Antichrists, Witches, and blind Guides,
Devils and Serpents, Liers, whose Call and Commission came from Oxford and Cambridge, the Sir Simons of the Age, Stewards of the Devils Magazine, a Viperous Generation of Disemblers and Blasphemers, holding a worm-eaten Beastly form selling Beastly Wares; The Letter which is Dust and Death, yea, greedy Dogs, Blood-Hounds, &c. So that should I inlarge on this Head I should repeat too much out of my former Books, which shew at large their contempt, not only of Scripture, Sacraments, and all-instituted Religion, but of all Christian Churches, Ministry and Magistracy; and that from plain matter of fact out of their printed and approved Authors; and therefore shall proceed to disprove their pretence of being the only Apostolical Church of Christ.

The Apostate Incendiary, &c. p. 3. Dear Friends, it was for your sakes and the Truth, that I was pressed in Spirit in a Godly Zeal thus to appear against this Deceitful Worker and Treacherous Spirit, which at length hath shewed it self in open Enmity against the Truth, Viz. The Church of Christ and Elect People of God, called Quakers, &c. By which 'tis plain, that they Arrogate to themselves, as Quakers to be the Church and Elect People of God. The next Proof, is out of their Book stiled, The Anarchy of the Ranters, &c. p. 1. That as the True and Pure-Principles of the Gospel are restored by (the Quakers) Testimony, so
The Ancient Apostolical Order in the Church of Christ is Re-established amongst them, and settled upon it's Right Basis and Foundation, &c. Thus do George Whitehead, and Robert Barkly, jointly agree, that the Quakers as such are the Church of Christ the Elect People of God. And then notwithstanding their contrariety to all Professors of Christianity; yet amongst them and by their Testimony, the ancient Apostolick Order of the Church of Christ is Re-established amongst them; and not only so, but settled upon it's Right Basis and Foundation: And then R. Barkly proceeds in his Preface to shew and assert the Power of their Church thus restored and settled amongst them, comparatively with that of the Apostles, and more particularly about the Power of decision and Judge of Controversies; which he one while to avoid Romes Infallibility, tells the World that they place the said Power in the Spirit of God; and tells us the Spirit of God is Infallible; a thing which no body denies; but by and by he does as positively place Infallability in the Members of their Church, as the boldest Romanists ever did or can do: As may be seen by the Question proposed, and his Answer to it of the same Book, in p. 66. Viz. Who is the proper Judge and Judges, in whom recideth the Power of deciding Controversies. Answer, This is that (saith Barkly) which I undertake in the next place to treat of; as being the Specifick Difference
and distinguishing Property of the Church of Christ, from all other Antichristian Assemblies and Churches of Man's Building, viz. To give a short, yet clear and plain Answer to this Proposition. The only proper Judge of Controversies in the Church of Christ is the Spirit of God, and the Power of deciding solely lies in it, as having the only unerring Infallible and certain Judgment belonging to it; which Infallibility is not necessarily annexed to any Persons or Places whatsoever, &c. Now by what is thus far said, in Answer to the said Question. A Man not skil'd in the Quakers Logick, would think them far enough from pretending themselves their Church, their Counsels or Ministers Infallible, but in p. 67. 68. The Fallacy is discovered, and the Snake in the Grass seen, viz. So that we say, and that with very good ground; that it is no ways inconstant with this sound and unerring Principle, to affirm, that the Judgment of a certain Person or Persons, in certain Cases is Infallible, or for a certain Person, or Persons, to give a positive Judgment, and pronounce it as obligatory upon others; because the Foundation and Ground thereof, is not because they are Infallible, but because in these things, and at that time they were led by the Infallible Spirit: And Therefore it will not shelter any in this Respect, to pretend I am not bound to obey the Dictates of Fallible Men; saying, is not this Popery. For there never will nor can be wanting in Case
of controversie, the Spirit of God to give Judgment through some or other in the Church of Christ, so long as any Assembly can properly, or in any tollerable Supposition be so termed.

From which it is both clear and Plain from Matter of Fact. That the Quakers not only claim to themselves the Name of the Church, but also that Infallibility to themselves, equal to that of Rome; and that themselves are Infallible; and upon that foot, their Sentences upon their Disciples so pronounced, are Obligatory, and ought to be Indispensibly obeyed, whether they be convinced of the Truth or Certainty of this their Judgment thus pronounced or no: And if this be not Rank Popery, I would fain know from George Whitehead what is; nor will their pretence to their being lead by the Spirit of God to give this Judgment be a Salvo; unless they can give a better Demonstration for their so saying, then their bare Affirmation; for that every Church may pretend to the Leading and Guidance of the Spirit of God as well as the Quakers: And hence I conclude, that if the Infallible Quakers Church, impose any thing on their Disciples, by Vertue of their Infallible Authority, to be indispensibly obeyed; that she produce a miracle to confirm and ratifie both her Commission and Sentence; or else grant that she own Infallibility in the same Sense the Papists do.

Again, that the Quakers account themselves the only Church; and as such Infallible,
see Josiah Coal's Works, p. 63. The Infallibleness of the True Church, of which Christ, is the Supreme Head and Governour, I do not go about to deny: But that the Church of Rome is Infallible; that I do deny, &c.

By which 'tis manifest, that the Quakers and Papists do not disagree about the Doctrine of Infallibility, and the power of their Sentences; and that the Disciples of each ought to obey whether they be perswaded in their Consciences of the Truth or Certainty of their Sentence or not: They only differ who of them twain be the Church: The one pretends to Miracles, so do the other; see the Papist Legends, and Fox's Journal. And 'tis plain that the Quakers, as well as the Papists say, That the Sentence of their Church, whether by a single Person or Persons Assembled in Council, once pronounced is obligatory upon their Disciples, and not to be rejected as the Dictates of fallible Men; For (say the Quakers as well as the Papists) There never will, nor can be wanting in Case of controversy, the Spirit of God to give Judgment through some or other in the Church, so long as any Assembly can properly, or in any tollerable supposition be so termed, &c.

Upon these and the like Positions some dissenting Quakers some Years since, charged the Foxonian Quakers with holding Romish Principles, 1. That we are to believe as the Church believe, 2. That the Church cannot
err, 3. That She hath power to bind and loose (as Geo. Fox did acknowledge he had; See Tyranny and Hypocrisy detected, &c. p. 45. Friends, altho' I have not told it you, I do now declare it, I have power to bind and to loose whom I please) 4. That 'tis abominable Pride not to submit to her Judgment (i. e. the Church) She having always the Infallible Spirit, &c. which said 4 Positions G. Whitehead in his Apostate Incend. &c. recites and very fairly vindicates them, read p. 16.17. viz. To the first I Affirm, That the True Church is in the true FaithThe 1 Quotation tell you that the Quakers are by G. W.'s own Doctrine the Church of X • . and Elect people of God. that is in God, and we must believe thus as the true Church believes, or else it were both a Folly and Hypocrisie to profess our selves Members thereof, &c. and proportionably he vindicates the other 3 Positions: But Rob. Barkly goes on in his Anarchy p. 42. saying That as through our faithful Testimony in the Laws of the Lord, that Antichristian and Apostate Generation, the National Ministry hath received a Deadly Blow, by our discovering and witnessing against their forced Maintenance and Tythes, against which we have Testified by many cruel Sufferings of all kinds, as our Chronicles shall make known to Generations to come: So that their Kingdom in the hearts of Thousands, begin to totter and loose its Strength, and shall assuredly fall to the Ground: So
do we by coming to Righteousness, weaken the Strength of their Kingdom who judge for Reward—the Nation shall come to be disburthened of that deceitful Title of Lawyers, as well as Priests, &c.

But notwithstanding the Quakers deadly Blow which they Dream they have given the Priests and Lawyers; they neither shake nor totter, but do continue as strong and their Foundation is as firm as when they begun to Strike; So that their Prophecy and Chronicles seems to prove Abortive. But W. Rogers wrote a smart Book against this of Barkly's, Entituled The Christian Quakers distinguished, &c. which did strike a deadly Blow against the Quakers Image of Church Government, to which Thomas Ellwood, as R. Barkly's Second, replyed by a Book stiled, An Antidote, &c. where he saith p. 1. I felt a just Indignation rise in my Soul against that unclean Spirit in (W. Rogers) which hath opened his Mouth in Blasphemy against the Truth and People of the Lord p. 152. and he unto whom all Power is given in Heaven and Earth, who is and will be with his Church to the End of the World, having now as well as then, given Gifts unto Men, and endowed them with Power from on high; invested some with an Heavenly Authority in the Truth, for the Edification and Preservation of the Body: There is the same reason and ground now to assert and vindicate the Authority and Power which
God hath placed in his Church, as there was then; And this being done by the same Spirit, and in the same Manner now as it was then; Thou (W. Rogers) canst squirt no filth upon these (G. Fox &c.) now which will not tend to bespatter them (the Apostles;) Take notice of that William, and consider it well, that all thy Revilings and Evil-Speeches against Friends in this day, do reflect as much upon the Apostles and Elders in the Primitive Church as upon Friends &c. p. 44. And this they (G. F. &c.) have laboured to do both by Words and Writings; by Word of mouth as opportunity has offer'd, and where by Voice they could not, there they have done it by Papers or Epistles given forth in the Light. Thus did the Apostles in their days, where divine Epistles are hereby vilifi'd, as well as those of Friends; and they themselves no less reflected upon p. 3. I know I touch a tender Point, and in a ticklish Time; wherein many Minds are possess'd with jealousies and fill'd with Surmisings p. 57. How dare you say that Geo. Fox hath taken upon him to give forth Directions and Instructions to others, when there are so many living Witnesses that what hath been given forth by him for Direction or Instruction to the Church, hath proceeded from the Spirit of God, &c. Again, Josiah Coal's Works &c. p. 93. All judgment (saith Coal) being Committed to the Light, that lighteth every
Man, the Light that is in every Man, must of necessity be the judge of all Controversies.

Reader, I have taken enough of Ellwood's Antidote, which is as strong-sented of Popery, as Rob. Barkly's Anarchy; and yet neither of them exceed Josiah Coal: However they [like Ahabs false] Prophets all agree in their main Fundamentals. And I shall shew from thence how arrantly they vye it with the Apostles, who were divinely Inspired, and gifted with Miracles to confirm their Commission: For say the Quakers, you may as well reject the Epistles of the Apostles as theirs; Affirming, that if any squirt any filth upon Geo. Fox or the Quakers, it must inevitably fall upon the Apostles. Again, if any reject the Epistles of Geo. Fox, &c. They consequently vilifie and reject St. Paul's Epistles; and Coal gives a Reason for it too, viz. Whereas Christ said, John 5.22. For the Father Judgeth no Man, but hath committed all Judgment to the Son, 27. And hath given him Authority to Execute Judgment also, Because he is the Son of Man, Matth. 28.18. And Jesus [who was Born of the Virgin] came and spake unto them saying, All Power is given unto Me, in Heaven and in Earth, so I say Coal's Reason is, because all Judgment is committed to the Light, therefore the Light that is in the Quakers must be Judge of all Controversies. His Doctrine Teacheth, that all Judgment
is committed to their Light: Their Light has Authority to execute Judgment, yea all Power in Heaven and Earth is given to their Light, and consequently their Light is the sole Iudge of all Controversy; and they the People whom this Light speaks through. And thus have they translated all Power and Authority, which was given to the Son of Man, Jesus of Nazareth, to their Light, and so unhinged the whole Frame and Constitution of Christ's Church and Government, from his Commands and Precepts left on Sacred Writ. Go ye therefore and Baptize, &c. Do this in Remembrance of me, &c. When you pray, say after this manner; forgive us our Trespasses, &c. Thus do they assert their power to be the same with the Apostles; that their Light hath the same power to judge, to command, to give precepts, as Jesus of Nazareth, the Son of Man had: For to their Light, all power in Heaven and Earth is given: Oh Horrid Blasphemy! in the highest degree. Again, see Ellwood's Antidote once more, p. 140. 141. Paul speaks of the Authority given him of the Lord. Did he usurp Authority? did he exercise a Power that belonged not unto him? doth he not say expresly, that the Lord had given it unto him? and wilt thou (William) charge him with falsehood? come, William, give over trifling, and speak out plain, either charge the Apostles with imposing upon the Churches, and cherishing an usurped Authority,
or fairly confess they had Power and Authority, Command and Rule, committed to them by the Lord; for the Edification of the Church: and if thou must grant it was so, then offer, at least, some shew or colour of Reason, why it may not be so now, or cease contending against it.

Having taken a large Proof, (unless I should quote their whole Books a thing impracticable) of the Quakers claim to the true Church, and the Order of it together, v z. Her Power and Authority to Rule and Command, Judge and Pronounce Definitive Sentence as Obligatory on their Disciples, as the Commands of the Apostles of our Blessed Lord upon the Primitive Christians and all Succeeding Ages: It may not be amiss to recite the Commandments of George Fox, the Quakers Lawgiver: I find Exodus the 20. Moses gave forth Ten Commandments: And George Fox, gave forth five, which the Quakers observe as strictly as the Jews ever observed those Ten of Moses's giving forth, George Foxes are as followeth, viz.
1. Thou shalt not pay Tythes to the Covetous Priests and Antichristian Impropriators.
2. Thou shalt not be Married by or with a Priest.
3. Thou shalt not put of thy Hat in Respect to thy Superiors.
4. Thou shalt not shut up thy Shop on the Worlds Holy Days or Fast Days; according to the Worldly Magistrates Command.
5. Thou shalt not pay towards the Reparation of Steeple-houses, nor thy Tax towards the Trained Bands.

Now Reader, observe, there are two things on which the Quakers Church Hingeth; one is, their Church you see have as they dream, the same if not greater Power then that of the Apostles touching Church Government, Power to Rule, Authority to Judge, and Infallible Direction to Pronounce their Sentence of Condemnation, Excommunication or Deprivation, and their Power Infatuated, and willingly Ignorant Disciples think themselves obliged to obey George Fox's Laws and Precepts, and the Authority of their Churches also; that Scripture Commands are not binding to them; for their Teachers have given them a Dispensation to break and violate them; but let me prove what I say: For the first, See William Penn's Brief Examination and State of Lib. Spiritual, &c. p. 11. And this I Affirm (saith William Penn) from the Understanding I have receiv'd from God; not only that the Enemy is at work to scatter the Minds of Friends, by that loose Plea; what hast thou to do with me? Leave me to my Freedom and the Grace of God in my self, and the like; but this Proposition and Expression, as now understood and alledged, is a Deviation from, and a Perversion of the Ancient Principle of Truth; for this is the plain consequence of this Plea; if any one shall say, I see no Evil in paying Tythes to Hireling Priests; in that they are not claimed by Divine Right, but by the Civil
Laws of the Land I see no Evil, (saith a 2d) in Marrying by the Priests, for he is but a Witness; I see no Evil (saith a 3d) in declining a Publick Testimony in Suffering Times; or hiding in time of Persecution; for I have Christ's and Paul's Example, I see no Evil (saith a 4th.) in Respecting Persons (by putting of my Hat to my Superiors) for whatever others do, I intend a sincere notice that I take of others, I know I see no Evil, (saith a 5th.) in keeping my Shop shut, upon the Worlds Holy Days, (or Fast Days.)

The Second Hinge, upon which their Church swing, and is founded, is in p. 47. of their Prophet, Edward Burrough's, viz. That is no Command from God to me, what he commands to another; neither did any of the Saints, we Read of in Scripture, act by the Command, which was to another, not having the Command to themselves; I challenge to find an Example for it, they obeyed every one their own Command &c. From whence 'tis plain; that Indispensible Obedience, is required to the Laws, Orders, and Commands, pronounced by the Quakers Church; but as plain, that their Leaders have let their Disciples loose from obeying Scripture Commands, unless they have them anew; as the Inspired. Apostles had, or can be convinced of their Obedience, which will hardly be by their Teachers Doctrine; as I have at large shewed in my Book: The Quakers Set, &c. p. 19. to 24. And having largely proved,
that the Quakers claims a Power over the Consciences of their Disciples; and that they hold those four Romish Positions, which have enslaved Nations, destroyed Thousands, and is of a most Dangerous and Pernicious Consequence; namely, that we are to believe as the Church believes; that the Church cannot err; that she hath Power to Bind and Loose; that in all Cases of Controversie, we ought to submit to her Judgment; she having always the Infallible Spirit; which Pernicious Doctrines are closely concluded, and boldly asserted by the Quakers, which I shall briefly summ up under these 12 Heads, and then leave them as a suitable motto upon them: And then proceed to the next Chapter, where I hope to shew, that the Quakers Church is so far from being the true Church of Christ; that it is in very deed the most Formidable Heresies that hath risen up in the Church, since the Days of Simon Magus.
1. That the Quakers are the Elect People of God, the only Church of Christ; amongst whom only is the Apostolick Order thereof restored, and settled on it's Right Basis and Foundation.
2. That it's not Inconsistent with this Quaker Church, to affirm that the Judgment of a certain Person or Persons, in certain Cases is Infallible, and being pronounced Obligatory on Believers.

3. Because their is not (say they) nor never will be wanting in the Church of Christ the
Spirit of God to give Judgment, through some one, or more of them that is Infallible; and consequently, decisive in the Quaker Church.
4. And on that Supposition, none can squirt any Filth on George Fox, or the Quaker's Teachers; but it must fall upon and affect Christ's Apostles and Prophets.
5. Also thereupon, whoever reject the Epistles of the Quakers, Vilifie and Condemn the Epistles of the Holy Apostles.

6. They deny the Church of Romes Infallibleness; right, yet they own the Doctrine of Infallibility; and that they themselves are Infallible at least in Controversial Cases, and some other Cases, which shew that they would justle out the Pope to bring in the Fox.
7. Whatever W. Rogers, &c. speak against George Fox, &c. equally Reflect on the Apostles.
8. That Thomas Eliwood was sensible he touched a Tender Point, and in a ticklish Time, in Asserting those Popish Positions, for which he is the less to be spared.
9. His timorousness in having his Book spread p. 232. greatly bewray his guilty Conscience.
10. Ellwood's boldness in daring any to charge G. Fox with taking upon him to give Directions to their Church, because (say Ellwood) it was the Spirit through him, consequently not G. Fox.

11. And therefore peremptorily bid W. Rogers either charge the Apostles with usurping
Authority over the Consciences, and imposing upon the Churches by vertue of his Commission; which would be Blasphemy, or else admit the Quakers may do the like to have the same Power, to exercise the same Dominion, which would be equal Blasphemy; or like a Troop of Armed Men going by a Court of Judicature, and should violently take the Judge out of his Chare, in which he is lawfully plac'd, invested with Legal Power; and in his Room set up a Thief who stole a Ministers Hour-glass, denied Christ Jesus, contemned the Scriptures, despised the Magistrates, reproached his Ministers, and ought to be Tryed whether Guilty or not Guilty.

12. That indispensable Obedience is required to G. Fox's Commandments, and the Quaker Church Sentences; but the Scripture commands no further obliging, then a Man meet with a conviction upon his Conscience, &c.

That these 12 Observations are the Natural consequences of the recited Doctrine of the Quaker Church; I stand ready to maintain on the Terms mention'd in my Book, New Rome Ʋnmask'd, &c. p. 89. And so I conclude this Chapter with a word of use and application to New Rome, &c.

lg.l: Rome's Sister thou art rightly styl'd
And with her may compare,
The Innocent thou hast beguil'd
Under pretences fair.
Hypocrisie, in thee is found
Thy Leaven, is not good
Thy deep deceit; thy Wit profound
In which thy confidence stood,
Is now come forth to open view,
That all may plainly see,
Thy art, thy craft, and well perceive,
Thy deep Hypocrisie.
How Proud, like to the Pharisee,
Thy Countenance appear,
And how like to the Romish See,
Thou dost thy Fabrick rear.
Thy Errors, which but few did see,
Are now become thy Crime,
And loaded therewith thou shalt be,
And that from time to time:
A crime from which thou canst not,
with all thy subtlety;
Clear thy self, 'tis such a blot
That on thy face doth lie:
As Rome thy Sister never had
At thy Age charg'd on her;
Nor any Crime half so bad,
At twice thy Age upon her.
Tho' She at length as Age grew on,
Through Her vile Imposition
Abhorr'd, became and grew a scorn
In every Christian Nation:
And dost thou think for to escape
With thy unwrit Traditions,
The stroaks which Protestants do make
Against thy Superstitions:
Against thy Errors and thy Pride,
'gainst thy Hypocrisies,
Against thy turning with the Tide,
And other Enormities.
No, no, I say, as thou art found
Treading the Papists Path,
True Protestants will thy Pride wound,
As Luther and others hath.
Thy elder Sisters Tripple Crown,
Whose Pride doth not exceed;
The Pride of thee which doth abound,
Exceeding Hers indeed.
Wherefore ye skilfull Archers bold,
Come forth and bend the Bow;
Let none escape as hath been told
Of Babel High nor Low;
But do to Her, as She to others have
As a just recompence;
She hath been Proud against the Lord,
And used violence.

div.head: CHAP. II.
Shews that the Quakers are not the Church of Christ, nor that the Apostolick Order thereof is restored amongst them, nor settled on its right Basis and Foundation; according to their vain boast.
div.p:
COme G. Whitehead, you tell us in your Apostate Incend. &c. 4. 'And as for our confessing, that we are the Church of the
'first born; let our Doctrine, Testimony, Lives, and Sufferings, bear witness, &c. Well then by your Doctrine, Testimony, Lives and Sufferings; you shall be Tryed and Measured, since 'tis a Rule of your own proposing; and herein you will find my Hand (as I told you) heavier upon you, since you will not abide by your own Proposition, in the Quakers Vindication, p. 4. And therefore prepare your self, and be not so dull and slow in your Answers; you know I have several Books extant unanswered, and some think unanswerable; and them you have answered, you have made but slubbering Work, leaving the most part unanswered; what is your Weapon ground blunt; is the Edge thereof turned, or are you corrected, and made thereby Silent; or will not the Quakers let you Write in their Vindication any longer; come George Answer me; you know you boast in your Book Judas and the Jews, &c. p. 55. saying, Indeed they are grown so Angry at our quick Defences; that some are fallen to Personal Criminations, &c. I well remember, that in Nine Months Time, you Wrote Three Books against me, Anno 1691. What are you weary of your quick Defences? Why are you so long taking Breath; you told me in one of your Books, the Church of England must provide better Tools; you see they have by their Books; The Snake in the Grass, &c. And Satan Disrob'd, &c. What are these Books too hard for you to Answer; come mend your Pen;
you see the Watchmen; (tho' not of the Night, as your Pupil Pennington call the Clergy, in his Discoverer Discovered, &c. p. 9. are awake, they begin to see you, and to view your Work, and do understand the nature of it; which is to overturn the Christian Religion, Root and Branch; tho' hitherto, you wrought so under ground, like Moles, that it was hard to set a Trap for you; but now you are taken and snared; and oh, how you toss and tumble, like a Wild Bull in the Net, and Write backward and forward; denying in one Book, what you confess in another, being confounded in all your Enterprises. I am ready to proceed, to try you by your own proposed Method; whether, you Quakers, be the Church of the First Born: I presume, it will appear otherwise; and I conceive it needful for you, to get your Brother Ellwood to your Assistance. Your Brother Barkly, boasts in his Anarchy, p. 16. viz. I find other Professors, make but small boast of any Proselytes; they get out from among us; I hear little of their proving Champions for the Principles of others against us, &c. Well what then; did you thereby take liberty to vend your Heritical Pamphlets; oh, George, you were too Secure, and Self-confident; you now see you are discover'd; and the Bowels of your Corrupted Cause ript up; and you need not now boast of the Champions you get from the Church of England: Alas; 'tis but here and there an unsetled Novice, that come over to
the Quakers, tho' you boastingly tell us as in Judas and the Jews, &c. p. 25. It seemed good to the Holy Ghost and to us, &c. Imitating, tho' unwarrantably, the Inspired Apostles, Acts 15.28. Come George now to the Tryal. And first, the Quakers Doctrine and Testimony, out of your printed and approved Books; which you say are given forth by the Eternal infallible Spirit of God; and that we may, by your Doctrine, as well burn the Bible as them: pray let us examine what you therein and thereby Teach.

1. A Question to Professors, &c. p. 27. Is not the Substance, the Life, the Anointing called Christ, wherever it is found, doth not the Name (Christ) belong to the whole Body, and every member in the Body, as well as to the Head? — so that the name is not given to the Vessel, but to the Heavenly Treasure in the Vessel, p. 29. and did not the Word, who was made Flesh, dwell and appear in a Tabernacle of Flesh, and cause the Glory of his divine Flesh to shine through that earthly Flesh. — Is it not as necessary, that the Eternal Word be made Flesh inwardly, as it was for him to take on him an outward body of Flesh, p. 33. Now the Scriptures do expresly distinguish between Christ and the Garment which he ware; between Him that came, and the Body in which He came: between the Substance which was Vail'd, and the Vail which Vail'd it: There was plainly He and the Body in which He came; there was
the Outward Vessel, and the Inward Life. This we certainly know, and can Never call the bodily Garment Christ; but That which appeared and dwelt In the Body, &c.

Observe, that in all this, and much more in this Book, how the Quakers Doctrine and Testimony differ from that of the Angels, Luke 2.10.11. And the Angel said unto them fear not, for behold I bring you Tydings of great Joy, which shall be to all the people: for unto you is born this day, in the City of David a Saviour, which is Christ the Lord, &c. now him that was born of the Virgin, the Angel called Christ; but the Quakers cannot do so, but the Substance in that Body; likewise Acts 5.30. The God of our Fathers raised up Jesus, whom ye slew and hanged on a Tree; him hath God exalted with his right Hand, to be a Prince and a Saviour, for to give Repentance to Israel, and forgiveness of Sins, Read Acts 10.38, 39. Again, Acts 1.9. While they beheld a Cloud received him out of their sight, and so on: It was not the Light within which was hanged on a Tree, which Ascended in the visible sight of the Gallaleans; and that should so come in like manner: Oh no, it was the same that was born of the Virgin, which the blessed Angels, and holy Apostles did bear witness unto; not as the Quakers, who say the Name Christ belongs to every Believer, as well as to the Head; which they cannot call Christ but something in him, which is in themselves as they Dream; that was not
born of Mary, that was not hanged on a Tree, that was not Crucified, Dead nor Buryed, nor nailed to the Cross; nor Run thorow with a Spear. This is the Quakers Christ. Thus do they, by their Doctrine and Testimony, acquit the Jews of crucifying Christ; which is a certain sign they are not the true Church, in that they render the Apostles false witnesses.

The Christian Quaker and his Div. &c. p. 97. The Serpent is a Spirit: Now nothing can bruise the Head of the Serpent, but something that is Internal and Spiritual, as the Serpent is; but if that Body of Christ (born of the Virgin) were the Seed, then could he not bruise the Serpents Head, in all, because, the Body of Christ is not so much as in any oneYes by Faith. and consequently the seed of the Promise is an holy and spiritual principle of Light, Life and Power; that being received into the Heart, bruiseth the Serpents Head; and because the Seed, which cannot be that Body, is Christ as the Scriptures testify. The seed is one, and that seed Christ, and Christ God over all blessed for ever. Observe, the Scriptures testify the contrary: They testify that the Body which was born of the Virgin, which was spit upon, which was nailed to the Cross, hanged upon the Tree, Dyed, Rose again and Ascended; which by a lively Faith dwelt in his Saints, was and is the Christ of God, the Seed of Abraham; of David which was promised, Gen. 3. And of this I
could give a 100 Script. Proofs, see New Rome Arraigned, &c. p. 55. to 66. Again, see W. Baily's Works, p. 300. A [Body] hast [Thou] prepared [Me] mark the distinction, [Thou] [Me] and a [Body] this [Me] that spake in the [Body] was the [Christ] p. 307. They [his Disciples] loved his Person for the sake of the frame and quality of the Spirit that dwelt in him, or else what was his Person to them more than another Person; but for that which dwelt in him, they loved him. Let none mistake me, I do not slight it, nor the Person of any of his Brethren or Children, as they are prepared to do the will of their Father. Observe, still the Doctrine of the Quakers Teach to deny him to be Christ, who was born of the Virgin, hang'd on a Tree, Run thorow with a Spear. For if only that which speak through his Body, viz. his Spirit, was the Christ of God; then are the Apostles found false Witnesses. and the Jews never crucified the Lord of Life and Glory: For the Quakers Light which they Dream to be Christ, was never crucified nor buffeted, nor crown'd with Thorns, nor run thorow with a Spear: Besides, 'tis plain that they value his Body, only for the sake of the frame and temper of the Spirit that dwelt in it; otherwise, say the Quakers, what was his Person more than another Person; Oh gross Blasphemy! What is this the true Church? No such matter, but the Synagogue of Satan: And to put all out of
doubt, that the Quakers Church deny Christ, read W. Smith's Primmer p. 36. Question, How may I know when Christ is truly Preached. Answer, They that are false (Ministers) Preach Christ without, and bid People believe in him, as he is in Heaven above: but they that are Christ's Ministers (the Quakers) Preach Christ within. Again, the Sword of the Lord drawn, &c. p. 5. Your imagined God beyond the Stars, and your carnal Christ is utterly denyed and testified against by the Light; to say that Christ is God and Man in one Person is a lye. Again, the sandy Foundation shaken, &c. by W. Penn. The vulgar Doctrine of satisfaction being dependant on the second Person of the imagined Trinity, of distinct Persons in the Unity of Essence Refuted, &c.

From all which 'tis Self-evident, that they deny Christ to be in Heaven above, at Gods right Hand; and that they own no other Christ, then what is within them. 2dly. Next their Blasphemy, to say that God and Christ in one Person is a lye, and testified against by the Quakers Light; as also the locality of Heaven is denyed: and lastly, the blessed Trinity contemned as an imaginary thing; and the Doctrine of satisfaction in depending on the second Person, Christ the Lord, Refuted and Rejected: Behold, and be Astonish'd at the blasphemous Doctrine and Testimony of the Quakers! Which G. Whitehead desires to be tryed by; whether they
be not the true Church of the first Born, yea forsooth, the Elect People of God. See also Saul's Errant to Damascus, &c. p. 8. He that hath the same Spirit that raised up Jesus from the Dead is equal with God, &c. which Spirit they all do pretend to have, and as a proof thereof, see what Josiah Coal says of Edward Burrow in his Epistle prefixt to his Works p. 1. And this I say and declare to all People, that He (Edward Burrows) was a Man Endowed with the Almighty Power of God, which Lived and Reigned In him; and the Treasury of pure, divine, heavenly Wisdom was Opened in him; — And so let all Friends wait upon the Lord in the feeling of the same Spirit that was in him, which is the Saints Comforter. Thus Reader you see that they are equal to God; possest with an Almighty Power, which none but God is; and that they encourage each other to wait in the feeling of the Spirit of a deceased Brother, and call it the Comforter, which Attribute is due to none but God, and his Son Jesus Christ; for as we ought not to pray to the deceased Saints, no more ought we to encourage any to wait in the feeling of the Spirit of a deceased Saint: but the Papists do both: See the conference between Dr. Reynolds and Hart about the Pope's Supremacy. p. 411. viz.
By the blood of Thomas,
Which he for thee did spend;
Make us, O Christ to climb
Where Thomas did Ascend.

Thus Reader you may see, that the Quakers Infallibility meet the Papist ☞ ☜ Hand in Hand. The Papist say, that their Saint Thomas Becket is Risen; so says W. Penn in his Epistle to Josiah Coal's Works, viz. And now he is truly Ascended, above and beyond every Trouble; and upon Mount Sion does he stand among the rest of our holy Brethren, &c.
The Papists go still on.

q.l: Oh Thomas reach thy Help to us,
Stay them that stand, help them that lie;
Correct our Manners, Deeds of Life,
Guide us unto the way of Peace;
All Hail, Oh Thomas, the Rod of Right,
The World's Light, the Churches Strength,
The Peoples Love, the Clergy's Joy;
All Hail brave Patron of the Flock,
Save them that on thy Honour Glee.

div.p: I find nothing in this Prayer of the Papists, but the Quakers have said as much to their Saints, when Living, and sometimes when Deceased; as this Instance of Edward Burrows, by Josiah Coal. 1st. That he was endued with the Almighty Power of God. 2dly. So let all Friends be incouraged to wait upon the Lord, in the feeling of the same Spirit that was Almighty, in him which we know is the Saints Comfort, &c.

The next Testimony, which I shall recite of this Josiah Coal's Adoration, shall be an Abstract of a Letter, he sent to George Fox, from the Barbadoes: In the Time of his Life, Dated, the 21 of March, 1658. And Vindicated
by William Penn, in his Book, Judas and the Jews, p. 58. viz. Dear George Fox, who art the Father of many Nations; whose Life hath reached through us thy Children, even to the Isles afar off; to the begetting many again to a lively Hope; for which Generations to come, shall call thee Blessed; whose Being and Habitation, is in the Power of the Highest; in which Thou Rulest and Governs in Righteousness, and Thy Kingdom is Established in Peace, and the Increase Thereof, is without end.

Come George, you referr us to your Doctrine and Testimony, to prove, that you are the Church of the First Born; but you are Condemned thereby, and found to be the False Church, the Mother of Harlots, and the Abomination of the Earth; in that you give Testimony to your Apostle, George Fox, and not to Christ Jesus; nay you rob Christ of his Divine Attributes, the Jewels of the true Church, and have decked, and therewith adorned your King George; for 'tis Christs Kingdom, that is Established in Righteousness; not George Foxes; 'tis Christ's Kingdom that shall have no end; not George Foxes; 'tis Christ's Kingdom that shall Increase; in which Christ himself Reigns in Righteousness, not George Fox, by all, which it appears, that the Quakers are not the Church of the First Born, of which, Christ Jesus is Head; but the Synagogue of the Self-righteous, and Self-exalted Pharasaical Church, of which,
George Fox was Head, &c. I remember, that Edward Burrows, in his Epistle saith, And as concerning the Quakers; what do you say of them; you have seen their Conversation, and do they not walk Justly; are they not Meek, Humble, and Sober; do they not take much Wrong; compare them with the Scripture. Answer, I have seen their Conversation, and when I come to treat of their Lives, I shall give an Answer. But Edward Burrows goes on. Then being prepared of the Lord went forth, as commanded of the Lord, and the Word of the Lord we sounded, and did not spare, and caused the Deaf to hear, the Blind to see, and the Dread of the Lord went before us; and first of all, our Mouths were opened, and our Spirit filled with Indignation against the Priests and Teachers, and with them, and against them; First, we began to War, as being the Causers of the People to err, and against them, as the Fountain of all Wickedness, abounding in the Nations; and as being the Issue of Prophaneness; shewing unto all People, that they were not Lawful Ministers of Christ, sent of him, but were Deceivers and Antichrists; and this was our first Work we entered upon, to thresh down the Deceivers, and lay them open, that all People might see their shame, and turn from them.

Well George, I see you can Magnifie your selves and boast of your Justice; your Humility, Sobriety, and Meekness; and so might
many of the Heathens; and perhaps with more reason, yet not the true Church of Christ, but Idolaters, and Blasphemers, nevertheless, and so are you; you say you begun with the Priests, then they did not begin with you, that your first Work, was to thresh them down, to discover and lay them open, that all People might turn from them; yet all are not turned from them to the Quakers; no, nor of late, since you have been discovered and laid open, few have turned to you, but many have left you, and begin to make War with you, and to thresh you, and lay you open, that People may leave you, and this angers you; well, but let us see another of your Idolizing Pamphlets, Wrote by one of your Humble, Meek, and Sober Ministers, wherein, he like Josiah Coal, aforesaid, most Blasphemously Attributes that to George Fox, due only to Christ, The Quakers Challenge, &c. p. 6. Stand up Muggleton the Sorcerer, whose Mouth is full of Cursing, Lies, and Blasphemy, who calls thy last Book a Looking Glass, for George Fox, whose Name thou art not worthy to take in thy Mouth, who Is a Prophet indeed, and hath been faithful in the Lord's Business from the beginning: It was said of Christ, that he was in the World, and the World was made by him, and the World knew him not; So it may be said of this true Prophet, George Fox, whom John said he was not; but thou will feel this Prophet one day, as heavy as a Milstone upon thee; and although the World knows him not, yet he is known.

Come George, what think you of this Testimony of yours, that say Christ was in the World, and the World was made by him, and the World knew him not; and So it may be said, by George Fox; what George, do you think that this Blasphemous Testimony will prove the Quaker Church, the Church of Christ; I tell you nay, you must first condemn these your Blasphemous Books, or else you will be made War with from Age to Age, and threshed from Generation to Generation; I must confess, he was one of your Prophets and great Teachers, and I know you are so much the loather to condemn his Books:
For, 1st. It was this, Sol. Eccles. which told that great Lie, in the Name of the Lord; saying, this Year, shalt thou John Story dye, who at that time was ill, yet lived about four Years after.
2. He, in the same false Prophecy, avouched Womens Meetings to be the Ordinances of Christ, when George Fox Ordained them.
3. This was he, that burnt his Fiddles on Tower-hill.
4. This was he, yea even he, that went to Bartholomew Fair stark naked, viz. a pan of Coals on his Head.
5. This is he, who in his Musick Lecture said, p. 22. viz. 'I do affirm, that if John (the Apostle) had said he had been a Sinner, he had lyed.

Yet the very same John, hath left it upon Record; that if we say, we have no Sin, we
deceive our selves, and the Truth is not in us, and that if we say, we have not Sinned, we make him (Christ Jesus) a lyer, and his Word is not in us, and the same John, was out of those Disciples, whom the Lord Christ Taught to Pray; Forgive us our Trespasses.
Yea, this is he, who says, in the Quakers Challenge, p. 3. That the Quakers are in the Truth, and none but they.

All this considered, 'tis not likely, that the Quakers will condemn the Infallible Meetings of such a Son of their Synagogue, much more of this nature I could collect; but having largely handled this Blasphemous part of their Doctrine and Testimony, in New Rome Arraigned, &c. and The Quakers Set, &c. I shall at present add no more.

Come George Whitehead; I have shewed how you deny Jesus of Nazareth, and Idolize each other, in and by your Doctrine and Testimony, and by both, it appears to me, that you are not the True Church; but since 'tis a Method of your own prescribing, I am willing to peruse it according to your own Terms, in proposing it, and when I have fully proved you not to be what you pretend you are, then let others judge; I hope this will account fair Dealing. And now I am come to your Doctrine and Testimony, concerning the Scriptures, and shall begin with one of your own Books.

George Whitehead's Service Apology, p. 46. That which is spoken from the Spirit of Truth
in any, is of as great Authority as the Scriptures and Chapters are, and greater. Again, George Whitehead's Ishmael, p. 10. 'That which is Written, is the Letter, which is Death, and killeth.

Saul's Errand to Damascas, &c. p. 7. All that do study to raise a living thing out of a dead, to raise the Spirit out of the Letter are Conjurers, the Letter of the Scripture is death and killeth, &c.
Several Petitions Answered, &c. p. 30. If ever you own the Prophets, Christ, and the Apostles, you will own our Writings, which are given forth by the same Power and Spirit.

Truth's Defence, &c. p. 2. 102. You might have as well condemned the Scriptures to the Fire, as our Writings, for our giving forth Papers and Printed Books, it is from the Immediate Eternal Spirit of God.

Davids Enemies Discovered, &c. p. 7. And these (the Apostles) do not call the Letter the Rule, and the four Books, Matthew, Mark, Luke, and John, the New Testament and Gospel; as thou and thy Generation, (the Priests) do, thy Ministry is in the Letter which killeth, &c. Writ by George Whitehead, and his Brother Christopher Atkinson.

The Quakers Refuge Fixed, &c. p. 17. Whether the first Pen-man or the Scripture was Moses, or Hermes, or whether both these are not one; or whether there are not many Words contained in the Scriptures, which were not spoken by Inspiration of the Holy
Spirit; whether some Words were not spoken by the Grand Imposture, some by Wicked Men, some by Wise Men, ill applied; some by Good Men, ill expressed; some by false Prophets, and yet true; some by true Prophets, and yet false.

News coming up out of the North, &c. p. 14. Your Original is carnal, Hebrew, Greek and Latin; and your Word is carnal, the Letter and the Light is carnal, the Letter and your Baptism is carnal; and your Sacrament is carnal; and their Communion is carnal; a little Bread and Wine, so Dust is the Serpents meat; their Original is but Dust, which is but the Letter which is death; their Church is Dust, so the Serpent feeds upon Dust; and their Gospel is Dust, Matthew, Mark, Luke and John, which is but the Letter, — p. 34. A Voice and a Word to all you Deceivers; who deceive the People, and Blasphemers, who utter forth your Blasphemy and Hypocrisie, that tell the People of a Sacrament, and tell them it is the Ordinance of God; blush, blush, and tremble before the Lord God Almighty; You who live in the witchery and bewitch the People.

Come G. W. I am willing you should have a fair Tryal; and if the Verdict come in that you are the true Church of Christ, and the Apostolick Order thereof, restored amongst you, and settled upon its Right Basis and Foundation; Then I hope the Protestant Clergy
will lay aside their Gowns, throw away their Bibles and turn Quakers; and that our Legislators, who not rightly understanding your Principles and Practices have already indulg'd you, will make Laws to defend you, and protect you; for if (as G. W. says) that which is spoken from the Spirit of Truth in any; and to be sure he means Quakers, (for they deny any other People to be a true Church, read Judas and the Jews p. 26.) be of more Authority than the Bible, what profit is it to read it? truly none; 'tis Conjuration by their Doctrine above told: and if so we may (as Fox and Hubberthorn says) even burn them, for we see, according to the Quakers Creed, the Scriptures are but Dust and dead Serpents Food; yea, Matthew, Mark, Luke, and John, all Dust, all Death, all Serpents Food; nay moreover, so uncertain (according to the Quakers Doctrine and Testimony) that whether Moses or Hermes be the first Pen-man of Sacred Writ, remains doubtful to them, and they would make it doubtful to others; still suggesting, that some of it was spoke by the grand imposture; some by wise Men ill apply'd, but what part of it I do not know; some by good Men ill expressed, neither know I that part; some by false Prophets, and yet true, neither know I that part; some by true Prophets, and yet false, neither know I that part. So that the Quakers Church has left us quite in the dark, and is very unintelligible: And 'tis plain that
this sort of Reasoning, of which I have given but a hint, tends to overthrow the Christian Faith, and to take away the divine Authority of the Scriptures; for take away what is received in the Holy Scripture, what was spoke by wicked and good Men, by Prophets true and false; and I would fain know what part of it they have left.

Now George, that you may have a fair hearing and a legal Tryal, according to your own proposed Method; whether you be the Church of the first born; since you have told us how to try you and measure you, let us know what you say of your own Writings, Epistles, and Books, for we have had a fair Sample of your Sayings of, and Judgment concerning the Scriptures, which being compared with your never Reading a Chapter or an Epistle of the Old or New Testament in any of your Religious Meetings (if so I may call them without offence to Christian Ears) do sufficiently shew that you deny the Scriptures, and consequently cannot be the Church of the first Born. Come George I first shewed your contempt of Jesus of Nazareth, 2dly. applauding and idolizing each other to a high Degree of Blasphemy, 3dly. I have shewed your contempt of the Scriptures, which together with your not Reading them in your Meetings, shew your plain denyal of them. 4thly. I am now coming to shew what George Fox, the Founder of Quakerism, says of himself. 5thly. and lastly, I shall set forth
your tender Regard and great Value you put upon your own Books, Epistles and Papers, which together with your Reading them, will demonstrate your Zeal for your own unwrit Traditions.

The Tryal of G. Fox at Lancashire Assize, &c. p. 21. And before I came to the Barr I was moved to Pray, and the Thundering Voice Answered, I have Glorified thee, and will Glorify thee again; and I (said G. F.) was so filled full of Glory, that my Head and Ears was filled full of it; and when the Judges came up, they appeared all as dead Men under me, alluding to Christ, John 12.28, 16, 14. and 17, 1.

2. Nows coming up, &c. p. 1. Written from the Mouth of the Lord, by one who is Naked, and Stands Naked before the Lord Clothed with Righteousness; whose Name is not known in the World; Risen up out of the North, which was prophesied of, but now it is fulfilled Geo. Fox.
3. Several Petitions Answered, &c. p. 60. My Name is covered from the World, and the World knows not Me nor my Name, &c. says G F.
4. Saul's Errant, &c. p. 8. He that hath the same Spirit that raised Jesus from the Dead is equal with God, &c. said G. Fox.
5 The Battle door &c. Introd. All Langu ges are to me no more than Dust, who was before Languages were, &c. G. Fox.

6. The Watcher, &c. p. 37. But to the end of all Disputes and Arguments I am come; for before they was I Am, &c. Alluding to John 8.58. Jesus said unto them, verily verily, before Abraham was I Am. So that the I Am in the Quakers, and the I Am in Christ, is all the Christ the Quakers own: And that this is so, see for further Proof W. Penn's Book. The Christian Quaker, &c. p. 69. And that must be their meaning, or else why should the greatest Teachers amongst them say, they were before all Languages were, which is many Thousands of Years since; and why should they say they were before all Disputes and Arguments were? which was before the Herds-men of Abraham and Lot; and that they were come to the end of all Disputes which is not yet fulfilled: But their Blasphemy is manifest, and Mr. Penn's Book, above quoted, clears the Point.

7. The great Mist, p. 89. Here thou hast shewed that the Quakers have a Spirit given them, beyond all the Fore-fathers which we (Quakers) do witness [and experience] since the days of the Apostles, in the Apostacy. And they [the Quakers] can discern who are Saints, who are Devils, and who are Apostates, without speaking ever a word, they that be in the Power and the Life of Truth.

8. Judas and the Jews, &c. p. 58. We need none to give us discerning or judgment;
Christ hath Furnished us already, and doth on all occasions.

Come Friend George, I think I have taken enough to shew you in your proper Colour, far out-striping Simon Magus, and all the Hereticks that ever I Read of, for Self-exaltation, which is no sign of your being the Church of the first Born; but a large Demonstration of the contrary.

1. You see G. Fox takes to himself the Voice from Heaven, John 12.28. Father glorify thy Name; Then came there a voice from heaven saying, I have both glorifyed it and will glorify it again, 29. the people said it thundered, others that an Angel spake to him.

2. Next you see Fox pretend to write from the Mouth of the Lord; and is not asham'd to say that he is Naked, nay, that he stands Naked, Clothed only with Righteousness; his Name is not known in the World; nay, so impudent was this Imposture, that he said in the 3d. Instance, that the World neither knew him nor his name, when there was not Ten Men in the County known better: Oh blush and be asham'd for ever, you Infatuated Quakers, that can thus swallow any thing; for either these sayings are G. Fox's, as laid down by me, or they are not; if they are not, why do you not meet me according to my proposition? and make it appear, as G. W. pretended to the Parliament, that I wrong you in Charge, Citation or Observation. If they be, why do you not
Renounce these Heretical and Blasphemous Principles; and let the Nation know that you disown and reject them.

4. Next you see, that Fox pretends to be equal with God; saying, that he hath the same Spirit that raised Jesus from the Dead, is equal with God; which Spirit, the Quakers in general own they have; oh, Blasphemy in the highest Nature.

5. You also see, that Fox tells you, he was before all Languages were, and that to him, they are no more then Dust; that is, no more then the Scriptures are; oh, you miserable deluded Souls, call'd Quakers; what are you quite blind, are you given up to strong Delusions; do not you perceive in all Whitehead's Answers; he takes no notice of most of my Remarkable Instances of your Rank Blasphemy.

6. Come you the Hearers amongst the Quakers; if there be but one grain of Sense remaining in you, tell me; do you think that James Parnell was before all Disputes and Arguments; was he before the Dispute between the Herdsmen of Lot and Abraham, tell me; do not pin your Faith upon Whitehead's Sleeve; if he tell you he was, do not believe him; for either he was, or was not; if he was, prove it to the World; if he was not, declare him an Imposture; deny his Doctrine, and publickly condemn his Book, so may you acquit your selves, and silence the Pens against you, and continue the Favour of the Government.

7. Come George Whitehead, are you not asham'd to be found vindicating such horrid Blasphemies and vile Imposters, come answer me; have you such a gift of discerning, as to know who are Saints, who are Devils, and who are Apostates, without speaking ever a Word; for you either have, or have not; if you have, why did you Write in Caters Narrative, viz. G. Smith, of Little Port, hath been convinced about 13 or 14 Years; and Ever Since he came amongst us, hath walked Ʋprightly according to his Measure, and have been of a Blameless Conversation from his Youth, p. 19. If you have not; why do you thus boast in your proud Self-exaltation, and thereby delude many well meaning People, who think all you speak and Write is from the Eternal Spirit, and thereby so Infallibly led, that none as in the 8th. Instance, need to give you discerning or judgment, when alass, I can give you 100 Instances of your manifest Fallibility and Dangerous, as well as gross Mistakes: And thus much briefly, to shew you as in a Glass, your manifest Hypocrisie, grand Blasphemy, and false Doctrine, which shew you are not the Church of the First Born.

Fifthly, and lastly on this Head, I am now about to shew you the Tender Care you have to preserve the Reputation and Authority of your own Books, Papers and Epistles, not a Word of calling them Dust, Death, and Serpents food; not a word of calling them Beastly Ware, the Chaff, the Husk, &c. Your
frequent Epistles you give to the Scriptures, not a word of what was spoken by Good Men, to be ill expressed by Wise Men, ill applied, no such matter; and first, let us see the care at your London Convocation, 1675.

div.head: London Yearly Meeting, May, 27. 1675.
div.p: 1st. It is our Sence, Advice, Admonition and Judgment, in the fear of God, and the Authority of his Power and Spirit, to Friends and Brethren in their several Meetings; that no such slight and contemptible Names and Expressions; as calling Men and Women's Meetings, Courts Sessions, or Synods; that they are Popish Impositions, useless and burthensome; that Faithful Friends Papers, which we Testitie have been given forth by the Spirit and Power of God, are Men's Edicts or Cannons, or embracing them, bowing to Men, Elders, in the Service of the Church, Popes, and Bishops, with such Scornful Sayings, be permitted among them; but let God's Power be set upon the top of that unsavory Spirit that uses them.

closer.signed:
Subscribed, by
William Penn.
George Whitehead.
Stephen Crisp.
and others

div.p:
2. To all People who meet in Steeple-Houses in England or else where, p. 2. So all you that have the Letter in England, and calls a Steeple-house a Church, and do not Worship God in Spirit; therefore to you all this is sent, as a Message from the Lord Jesus Christ in England,
and elsewhere; into all Steeple-houses or elsewhere, to be Read; and God is the same, he is a Spirit, and his Spirit is drawing from all Steeple-houses; now where it is Ruling; and they [the Clergy] tell People of a mediate Call; so they are in their Witchcraft It was seldom in those Dayes, that any of your Epistles came forth; but the Clergy were termed Witches, Baal's Priests, Conjurers, or the like hateful Names. and Whoredom; Christ is not in the Letter, nor the Life is not in the Letter; this mediate Stuff hath reigned long in the Cage, Come George Whitehead; what reason have you to be angry with me, for putting 20 or 30 of your Ʋnclean Birds into a Cage; when you call the Church of England a Cage of Ʋnclean Birds. Of Ʋnclean Birds: Now in this our Age, we [Quakers] who have the Spirit, which gave forth the Scriptures, which the Apostles were in; And this is to go abroad into all Steeple-houses in the Nation, and their High Places, and through the World, that they may come to God from them, &c.

3. This is only to go amongst Friends, p. 19. And Thou Oh North of England, who art counted as desolate and barren; and reckoned the least of the Nations; yet out of Thee did the Branch spring, and Star arise which gives Light to the Regions round about. In Thee the Son of Righteousness appeared with Wounding, and with Healing; and out of Thee, the Terrors of the Lord proceeded, which makes the Earth to tremble,
out of thee, Kings, Priests, and Prophets, did come forth.—Lift up your Voices, blow the Trumpet, gird on your Swords on your Loins; ride on, ride on my beloved Brethren, and follow Souldiers, make all plain before you; thresh on with the new threshing Instrument which hath Teeth; beat the Mountains to dust, make the Heathen tremble, and the Uncircumcis'd fall by the Sword, spare none, neither Ox, nor Ass; neither Old nor Young, kill, cut off, destroy, bathe your Sword in the Blood of Amaleck; and all the Aegyptians and Philistines, and all the Uncircumcised, and hew and gag to Pieces; break the Rocks, cut down the Cedars and strong Oaks; make the Devils Subject, cast out the unclean Spirits; raise the Dead, shut up in Prison, bring out of Prison, cast in your Nets, lanch into the deep; divide the Fish, bind the Tares in bundles, cast them into the Fire; thrust in your Sickles, reap the Earth, silence all Disputers and Diviners; for ever trample upon all the Chaff and Dung and Mire for ever. Put on your Armer, gird on your Sword, and lay hold on the Spear, and march into the Field, and prepare your selves to Battle; for the Nations doth defie our God; arise, arise, sound an Alarm, and make their Ears Tingle; our Enemies are whole Nations and Multitudes in number, a Rebellious People, that will not come under Our Law; stand upon your Feet, and appear in your Terror, as an Army with Banners; and
let the Nations know your Power, and the stroak of your Hand; cut down on the right Hand, and slay on the left, and let not your Eye Pitty, nor your Hand Spare, but wound the Lofty, and tread down the Honourable of the Earth, and let none of the Heathen Nations, nor their God's escape out of your Hands, nor their Images, nor their Idols; but lay wast Fenced Cities, and tread down the High Walls, for we have Proclaimed open War: Your Captains are Mighty Men, and your Leaders are Skill'd in handling the Sword; and cursed be every one that riseth not up to the help of the Lord against the Mighty, &c.
4. A general Epistle to all the upright Israelites born of the Seed. This is only to go amongst Friends, and not otherwise W. Smith's Works p. 77.
5. An Epistle to the Righteous Congregation, who in the Light are gathered to be Read amongst them, when Assembled together W. Smith's Works p. 84.
6. An holy Kiss of Peace, sent from the Seed of Life, greeting all the Lambs and little Ones, &c. W. Smith's Works p. 89.
7. An Alarm beat in the Holy Mountain by Commission from the Prince of Peace, in W. Smith, see his Works p. 46.
8. An Epistle to all the Called and Chosen of God, to be read among Friends in the Power of Wisdom and Truth, W. Smiths Works, p. 215.
9. Two General Epistles to the Flock of God, where ever dispersed, by Margaret Fell and J. P. Printed, 1664.
10. To Friends in England, Ireland, Scotland, Holland, New England, Barbadoes, or any where else, where the Lord shall order this to come.
11. The Word of the Lord to Sion, the New Jerusalem, the Bride, the Lambs Wife, tho Excellency of all the Glory that is amongst the People, by W. D. Printed, 1664.
12. An Epistle to Friends every where, to be read distinctly in their Meetings, by K. W. Printed, 1681.
13. All Friends every where, this is the Word of the Lord unto you all; this may be read amongst the Children of the Light, and of the Day, George Fox.

14. An Epistle to the Remnant of Friends, by George Whitehead, concluding thus, viz. Let this be read distinctly in the Life and Authority of God, (from whence it came) amongst Friends, in and about the City of London, or elsewhere, as any are moved in the same Life.
15. To the Children of Light, &c. I desire this Epistle may be read in your several Meetings, William Penn.

16. Several Papers given forth for the spreading of Truth, &c. I charge you in the Presence of the Lord God, to send this [Epistle] amongst Friends and Brethren every where in all Meetings: To you all, this is the Word of the Lord God, &c.

Reader, the reason why I recite so many of their Epistles is to shew, that though the Quakers have condemned the Holy Scriptures, and never read a Chapter or an Epistle of the Apostles in their Meetings for Worship, yet you may see how Careful and Industrious they are to send their Heretical Epistles up and down, as the Word of the Lord, the Word of the Lord God; let this, that, and the other, be read distinctly in the Life and Authority of God, from whence it came. I have 2 Epistles from the London Convocation, and shall recite part of them, as a further Proof of their blind Zeal, as if the Holy Scriptures were defective and not proper to spread Truth; but to the said Epistles; and then after some brief Observation, I shall conclude this Chapter, touching the Quakers two Points, viz. Their Doctrine and Testimonies, &c.

17. An Epistle to the Monthly and Quarterly Meetings of Friends in England and Wales, or elsewhere; from our yearly Meeting, held in London the V. VI. VII. and VIII. Days of the 4th. Month, 1693. p. 2. Several other Epistles from Forreign parts; as Barbadoes, Merryland, Pensilvania, Virginia, Scotland, and Holland were read; an Epistle from Amsterdam in Holland. Ja. Dickinson and Tho. Wilson at this Meeting gave an account of their Travels in Barbadoes, East and West Jersey, Pensilvania, Merryland, Virginia, New England, North Carolina, Rhoad-Island, Long-Island, Antego, Nevis, &c. 4 Epistles from
Ireland; an account was given of Danerzick Friends; a Letter also from Jamaica, that there is a People raised up and increased in Germany among the Lutheranes called Pietists, by some called Quakers, persecuted by the Duke of Saxony and the Priests: Several of our Friends Books have been spread amongst them, p. 3. It's desired that the Monthly and Quarterly Meetings respectively take notice of all Friends Books, that are, or may be sent to them, according to former Agreement; and take care for the dispersing the same for the Service of the Truth, &c. And take care to advise the Correspondents in the Counties, to write only to your Correspondents in London about their Sufferings.

18. Renewed advice to the Respective Monthly and Quarterly Meetings in England and Wales, for the preserving and spreading Friends Books, for the Service of Truth, Signed on the behalf of the Meeting, the 18. Day of the 6th. Month, 1693. Benja. Bealing.

p.q: Our Friends have at several yearly Meetings, considered how those Books, Printed for the Service of Truth, might most effectually be spread; and at the last yearly Meeting it was left to this Meeting, who have settled as followeth.

Those that Print Friends Books, within a Month at most, send to one of the Correspondents of the several Counties for each Meeting, two Books of a sort, if under 6d.
and one of a sort if above 6d. for these Reasons.

div.p: 1. For Friends to have general notice what Books are Printed.
2. That they may send for what Quantities they see meet.
3. That the Printer may be incourag'd,
4. That one Book of a sort may be kept in each Monthly and Quarterly Meeting.

p.q: Dear Friends and Brethren, it's tenderly advised and recommended to you; that you be careful and diligent in the spreading of all such Books that are Printed for the Service of Truth; and are written either in Defence of it, or by way of Epistle, Warning, Caution, Exhortation, or Prophesy. The Printer's Name is as follows; to whom direct thus: For Andrew Soale, at the crooked Billet in Holy-well-Lane, in Shoreditch, London; or to Thomas Northcoat at his Shop in George Yard in Lombard-Street, London: And this we think needful you should Record in your Quarterly Book, and sometimes read it for remembrance and notice, &c.

div.p: For more of this Nature, with the dangerous Consequences attending their Practice, see my Book, the Quakers set in their true Light; &c. p. 20. to p. 47.

Reader, I am willing to give a brief Account of the nature of their Epistles; and the Titles; and the Reason why I enlarge thereupon. The 1st. Epistle was from the
yearly Meeting 1675. wherein they are plain and positive, that their Papers are given forth by Divine Inspiration, and as such; and that they arrantly guard against such slight Names and Expressions, as Edicts, Canons, &c. which are Names and Titles Honourable enough for all humane Writings: But the Holy Scriptures you see, the very same Men can call Dust, Death, carnal Letter, beastly Ware, Serpents Food, &c. And yet have they the Impudence to say they value the Bible above all Books extant: And as to the 2d. The very title carries the Picture of a Quaker; for who but such a one, void of all Modesty and Charity, could have given out a non sensical Paper as a Message from the Lord Christ; when there is scarce a Sentence in the whole that Teach any point of Doctrine relating to the Fundamentals of the Christian Religion; telling the Ministers they are Witches, and in Witchcraft a Cage of unclean Birds; that God is calling People from thence, &c. Nay observe the universality; it was to go thro' the World. Surely had the Church of England accepted of the Quakers new Service-Book, after the Bible was Condemned by the Quakers; and Matthew, Mark, Luke, and John Sentenced to be only Dust, Death, and Serpents Meat; we should have had new Bibles, a new Liturgy, a new Religion, a new Gospel, yea, and a new sort of Ministers • oo. See New Rome Arraign'd, &c. p. 43. for more of this. As to the 3d. We must observe, that was only
to go amongst the Quakers, for it is so Entituled, viz. This is only to go amongst Friends. And indeed it's fit to go amongst no other People; for it's very plain that they put the North of England for the Town of Bethlehem, and the branch the Star, the Son of Righteousness: They most Wretchedly and Blasphemously attribute to G. Fox, who rose out of the North as abovetold, and at large in his Book, News coming up, &c. For all those Scriptures which mention the Branch, the Star, the Son of Righteousness, the Town of Bethlehem, they all refer to Christ, for to him give all the Prophets witness, and not to Geo. Fox, read Luke 10.34. Numb. 24.17, 19. Zach. 3.8. cap. 6. v. 12. Mal. 4.2. Micah 5.2. and to this agree St. Matth. 2.6. Neither will this peace of Blasphemy seem strange to such as are acquainted with the wild Doctrine of the Quakers; for the whole Epistle which contains 24 pages in Quarto, hath little or nothing in it, but a parcel of affected Rhetorick, senseless and useless; for if the Quakers were forced to interpret it, and explain their meanings; they must conclude it either relates to the inward or outward State of Mankind: If they say the outward, then 'tis desperate, and seems to be only calculated for the use and service of the Fifth Monarchy-Men: If they say they apply it all inward, then 'tis such Nonsense and Bedlam-Stuff as the like never was heard; what Heaven and Hell within the Trumpets,
the Swords, the Mountains, the Spears, Ox and Ass, Rocks and Valleys, Fish, Tares, Chaff, Dung and Mire, all within; what Miracles, Fish and Net, all within; I am more large on this Subject in New Rome Ʋnmask'd. But before I go further let me add an Abstract of a Letter, sent from John Audland to Geo.
