Fox out of the West of England, which may lead us to believe, that the Quakers did believe the North of England was the Town of Bethlehem, and that the Branch the Star, the Son of Righteousness were applicable to their Prophet Fox. viz. Dear and Precious One, in whom my Life is bound up, and my Strength in thee stands; by thy Breathings I am nourished, by thee my Strength is renewed, blessed art thou for evermore; and blessed are all they that enjoy thee: Life and Strength comes from thee, Holy One; —dayly do I find thy presence with me, which doth exceedingly preserve me, for I cannot Reign but in thy Presence and Power. — Pray for me that I may stand in thy Dread for evermore — I am thine, begotten and nourished by thee; and in thy Power am I preserved, Glory unto thee, Holy One, for ever.

Now as to the Titles of the other Epistles, some were only to go amongst the Quakers, particularly the 4th. And having in my former Books enlarged on this Head, I shall only remind the Reader what horrid Names and contemptible Expressions they cast upon
the Scriptures; and to confirm to us their dis-esteem of them; they did never read, nor do they yet read any one Chapter in their Religious Assemblies (if I may call them so) and you see how frequent they read their own; yea, G. Fox Charges and Commands them to read his Epistle, and that too, as the Word of the Lord God: All which shew that the Quakers are not the Church of the first Born, but such a Tribe of Hypocrites and false Pretenders as never appeared since the days of Simon Magus: This is the Charge I give them, and stand ready to prove them guilty of the Errors contained in this Chapter; to which let me subjoyn a word of Use and Application.

lg.l: Come Quakers all, and answer to my Charge,
I have not time to draw it out at large;
For if I had, and should the same design;
For Every Error, I cou'd draw out nine.
Your Books are full, and your Epistles all,
So swell'd therewith, even Errors great and small:
Such as no Sect, save yours, that's known to me,
Afford the like; this I do clearly see:
And could be glad, to see you them retract;
Condemn and censure, yea with all my heart:
I have no pleasure, them to enumerate;
But rather mourn, for to behold your State.
And were it not, that others might be warn'd,
And you, your selves, precaution'd, and forewarn'd:
I silent should remain for ever, and
Enjoy my self, in this my Native Land.
Search the Scriptures, as Christ himself advise,
With Reverence, and then you'll highly prise,
The Prophecies fulfill d, you there will find;
Which may confirm, and satisfie your Mind.
And they do teach, that Salvation's in none;
So rightly plac'd, as in His Name alone:
Who of the Virgin, in due time was born;
Who liv'd, and dy'd, for Man's Salvation.
Read Acts the 10th, and every Chapter there;
And Pauls Epistles too, which do declare;
The Prophets too, yea holy Men of Old,
Avouch the same, it cannot be control'd.
Answer my Books also, or you'll be blam'd,
As not able, or else quite asham'd;
It is but fit, that you should now discover
Your Principles, and no longer smother:
Wherefore come forth, of your close Dens and Holes,
Into the light, and not lye hid like Moles,
Under the ground, or like some night blind bate.
Avoid the Light, this is a dismal State.
Come forth, I say, appear in the Field;
Put on your Weapons, yea, also your Shield:
For shame, I say, remain no longer mute,
Nor cowardly, or fearful to dispute.
Remember how you to the Bishops call;
To Learned Doctors, yea to the Clergy all;
For to come forth, and meet you in the Field;
As if so arm'd, as not design'd to yield.
What are you storm'd? what are you put to flight?
Or are you weak, or are you in a fright?
Where's, now your Stones, your Slings your Sword, your Bag?
Where is your Tongue; why does it not now wag?
Where is your Zeal? Where is your Boasting now?
What is it lost? Or do you know not how
To answer me, or to defend my Charge;
What will you then; if I should then enlarge?
You see I can, if that there be a need;
Altho' unwilling, against you to proceed:
But since that you, your Errors do maintain;
'Tis just also, my Charge be very plain.
To Write no more, I long since did intend;
But none but God, now know when I shall end.
For still I find, when I think all is done,
As much to Write, as when I first begun.

div.head: CHAP. III.
Shew that the Quakers Lives do not bear witness, that they are the Church of the first born; but contrariwise a Pharisaical Synagogue.
div.p:
THere are four things proposed by the Quakers, by which they are willing to be Tryed and Measured, whether they be not the Church of the First-born; namely, by their Doctrine, by their Testimony, by their Lives, and by their Sufferings. The two first I have
gone through, and shewed that by their Doctrine, they deny Jesus of Nazareth to be the Christ of God; that they deny the Scriptures by their Contempt cast upon them; as calling them Death, Dust, Beastly Ware, Serpents Food, &c.

And that by their Testimony, they agree not with the Prophets of old, Acts the 10th. 43 To him [Christ] gave all the Prophets Witness; that through his Name, whosoever believeth in him, shall receive Remission of Sins, &c. Neither do the Quakers Testimony agree with the Holy Angels, Luke 2.10.11. And the Angel said unto them, fear not, for behold I bring you good Tidings of great Joy, which shall be to all People: For unto you is born This Day, in the City of David, a Saviour, which is Christ the Lord, &c. Neither do the Quakers Testimony agree with the Holy Apostles, Acts 5.30.
The God of our Fathers raised up Jesus, whom ye slew and hanged on a Tree; him hath God exalted with his right Hand, to be a Prince and a Saviour, for to give Repentance to Israel, and Forgiveness of Sins, &c.
Neither do the Quakers Testimony agree with the Martyrs, Acts and Mon. p. 610. I am come hither (said Dr. Barnes) to be burned as an Heretick; hearken to my Faith: I Believe in the Holy and Blessed Trinity; I believe that Christ Jesus suffered Thirst, Hunger, Cold, &c. As more largely, in the Quakers Ʋnm. p. 19. 20.
For first, the Quakers give Testimony to George Fox, as the Branch, the
Star, the Son of Righteousness, and put the North of England, for the Town of Bethlehem. And whereas 'tis plain, that the Blessed Angels, Holy Apostles and Martyrs Testified to a Christ that was born in the City of David, that was hanged on a Tree; that suffered Thirst, Hunger, Cold, &c. The Quakers plainly say; that this is not the Christ: See The Christian Quaker, and his Div. &c. p. 98. But on the contrary, they bear Testimony to their Light to be Christ which was not born of the Virgin Mary, at the Town of Bethlehem, and City of David; was not hanged on a Tree, pierced with a Spear, Crowned with Thorns; did never suffer Hunger, Cold, nor Thirst; and that the Trinity is only Imaginary, and by them rejected. And since their Testimony and Doctrine, thus differ from the Testimony and Doctrine of the Glorious Angels, Prophets, and Holy Apostles, and Blessed Martyrs, and all Christian Churches to this day. I do thereupon conclude, the Quakers are not the Church of the First Born; but a formidable Heresie lately risen: But that George Whitehead, may not complain of not having a full Hearing, and his Witnesses heard. I shall go on, God willing, with his other two Evidences; namely, the Quakers Lives and Sufferings; but first their Lives, which I must divide into two parts. First, their Lives, as Christians, (since so they would be accounted) Respecting their Obedience to the Christian Doctrine, Precepts and Commands. Secondly,
with Respect to their Holy Living, which they think exceed all the World; besides, else why should they give it as an Evidence of their being The Church of the First Born; since many Heathens, respecting their Conversation, exceed most of the Quakers. But one thing the Quakers forgot; for they have a 5th. Evidence; namely, their Miracles Recorded in Foxes Journal; but that would have been like the rest: For as the Apostles wrought Miracles in the Name of Jesus of Nazareth; Fox wrought his Miracles in his own Name, like Simon Magus. So that had they produced their Miracles as an Evidence of their being the Church of the First Born; it would like the other four, have been a means to have proved the quite contrary; but to the matter.

Christ Jesus to whom all Power in Heaven and Earth is committed; who is Head and Law giver to his Church, gave forth several Commands and Precepts; and did in the days of his Flesh Institute and Ordain the Sacraments of Baptisme and the Lord's Supper; and told us how and after what manner to Pray. Now if the Lives and Practices of the Quakers do evidence to the World that they are found in the practice of the same; then it will be a sign, that they may be admitted to be a Church, tho' not the only Church, since many Christians are found in the practice of them: But on the other hand, if the Quakers shall continue to say we are divinely Inspired as well as the Apostles, and
have the same Power, Rule, Command as they had; and our Writings are given forth by the Eternal Spirit, as Infallible as St. Pauls, and that if any squirt any filth upon us it will be spatter the Apostles; and if any reject our Epistles, they vilifie the Apostles, for we are inspired as well as they: We can give forth Commands, Exhortations and Precepts all well as they, for all Judgment is committed to the Light in us, yea, all Power in Heaven and in Earth; and we can work Miracles as well as they; and therefore whether you will reckon us the only Church of Christ (as we would be accounted or only one of the Protestant Churches; it's all one we will not come under the Power of your Scripture Commands; for one of our Apostles have laid it down for Infallible Doctrine, see Edward Burrow's Works p. 47. That is no Command from God to me, what he Commands to another, neither did any of the Saints which we read of in Scripture, act by the Command which was to another; not having the Command to themselves; I challenge to find an example of it: They obeyed every one their own Command, &c. And our beloved Brother W. Penn in his Rejoynder says, in Vindication of the said Doctrine, viz. No Commands in the Scripture are any farther obliging upon any Man, then as he finds a Conviction upon his Conscience, otherwise Men should be engaged without if not against Conviction, a thing
unreasonable in a Man, &c. So that tho' our Leaders require of us submissive Obedience to their Laws; and that we ought to believe as our Church believes, yet they have left us at Liberty from the Jurisdiction of your Scripture Commands, and we not being convinced that Water-Baptisme is commanded, Matth. 28.19, 20. Go ye therefore and teach all nations, baptizing them in the name of the Father, and of the Son, and of the Holy Ghost; teaching them to observe all things whatsoever I have commanded you, and lo I am with you always, even to the end of the world. Again, Luke 22.19, 20. And he took bread and gave thanks, and brake it and gave unto them saying, this is my body given for you: Do this in remembrance of me. And tho' we find this literally commanded, yet our Teachers tell us that the Scriptures are Dust, Death, beastly Ware, Serpents Meat; and that unless our Light, to whom all Judgment in Heaven and Earth is committed, and is the sole judge of all Controversies, convince us we are not concluded, and thereupon we reject them as beggerly Elements. And moreover, our Teachers tell us they are Deceivers and Blasphemers that tell us of a Sacrament, and for which they ought to Blush and Tremble; And that Water-Baptisme is an Institution which rose from the Whore of Rome; and that the practice of it is Idolatry, as in News coming up, p. 34. Burrow's Works, p. 51. 518. Smith s Primmer, p. 36. A Musick Lecture, p. 25.
And these Arguments, nor our Light within do convince us; and thereupon we reject them, and do neither Baptize with Water, nor Receive the Sacrament; And this we are not ashamed to proclaim to all the World, both by our Doctrine, Testimony, our Lives, Practice and Conversation, &c.

To all which I thus Answer, in the Affirmative, That these Commands are plain and positive; and without which you cannot be the Church of the First Born, but will be condemned and cast; neither am I alone in this my Sentence, read the History of the French Protestants, Entituled Synodicon in Gallia Reformata, p. 16. Article 37. 38. We do believe that both in Baptism and the Lord's Supper God doth indeed truly, and effectually give whatsoever he doth there Sacramentally exhibit; and therefore we do conjoyn with the Signs, the true possession and enjoyment of what is offered to us in them: Therefore we do affirm, that they which do bring pure Faith as a clean Vessel unto the Holy Supper of the Lord; they do indeed Receive that which the signs do there witness, That is, that the Body and Blood of Jesus Christ are no less the Meat and Drink of the Soul, than Bread and Wine are the Meat and Drink of the Body: We say therefore, let the Element of Water be never so despicable; yet notwithstanding, it doth truly witness unto us the inward Washing of our Souls with the Blood of Jesus Christ,
by the Vertue and Efficacy of his Spirit; and that the Bread and Wine being given us in the Lord's Supper, do serve in very deed unto our Souls nourishment, because they do as it were point out to us with the Finger, that the Flesh of Jesus Christ is our Meat, and his Blood our Drink, by and through the Vertue and Efficacy of his Blessed Spirit; and we reject those [pretended Churches] as will not receive such signs and marks. Again, p. 12. ibid. Article 28. In this Belief we protect, that where the Word of God is not received, and where there is no professed subjection to it; and where there is no use of the Sacraments; if we will speak properly, we cannot think there is any [true] Church.

Come G. W. What think you now? What starting hole have you in store? And what have you more to say for your selves, why Sentence of Condemnation should not be pronounced against your being the Church of the First Born; you see the Commands of Christ, the Practice of the Apostles, Primitive Christians, Saints and Martyrs, in all Ages stand Witness against you and your Antichristian Practices.

Again, all Christian Churches, since the Days of Christ, have frequently in their Prayers to God, made Confession of their Sins, and beg'd Pardon for Jesus Christ his sake: This I am sure no Christian will deny; for so hath Christ Taught us in that most
Excellent Form of Prayer, Matth. 6. Luke 11. saying, When you Pray say after this manner; Our Father, &c. forgive us our sins as we forgive them that trespass against us, &c. But the Quakers do not Pray after this manner; for they make no Confession of Sins to God, nor beg pardon for Christ's Sake, neither in their publick Prayers in Meetings, nor is there such an Expression to be found in all their Books; if any think I wrong the Quakers herein, let them read and search as I have done, and shew me such a passage if they can: I have read great part of the Books following, besides many others; And also, I was more than 25 Years a Member of their Society, and I can neither remember, nor yet find in the Books following such a passage, which are these,
E. Burrow's Works in Fol. containing Pages 896
Sam. Fisher's Works in Folio. 954
Fr. Howgill's Works in Folio. 709
G. Fox's Journal in Folio. 632
G. Fox's Great Mist. in Folio. 407
W. Smith's Works in Folio. 565
W. Penn and G. W.'s Christian Qua. in Folio. 555
W. Baily's Works in Quarto. 774
R. Hubberthorns in Quarto. 474
W. Penn's Rejoynder Pag. 451

Reader, I have given you a tolerable sample of their Books which I have searched, yea and many more, yet I cannot find such a passage; and therefore if thou art a Quaker, and have but a spark of Christianity
left in thee, I admonish thee, nay I intreat thee to consider of these Scriptures following.

John 1.8. If we say we have no sin we deceive our selves and the truth is not in us, v. 9. If we confess our sins, he is faithful and just to forgive us our sins and to cleanse us from all unrighteousness.

Psalm 38.18. For I will declare mine iniquity; I will be sorry for my sins, 51.1. Have mercy upon me, O God, according to thy loving kindness, according unto the multitude of thy tender mercies blot out my transgressions, v. 2. Wash me throughly from mine iniquity, and cleanse me from my sins, v. 3. for I acknowledge my transgression, and my sin is ever before me, read Psalm 40.15.
Isa. 64.6. But we are all as an unclean thing, and all our righteousness as filthy rags; and we all do fade as a leaf, and our iniquities like the wind hath taken us away.
Lam. 3.20. Let us lift up our hearts with our hands unto God in the heavens, we have transgressed and have rebelled.
Job 7.20. I have sinned, what shall I do unto thee, O thou preserver of men?
Prov. 20.9. Who can say I have made my heart clean, I am pure from my sin?
Eccles. 7.20. For there is not a just man upon earth, that doth good and sinneth not.

Nehem. 1.6. Let thine ear now be attentive and thine eyes open, that thou may'st hear the prayer of thy servant, which I pray before thee
day and night for the children of Israel, thy servants; and confess the sins of the children of Israel which we have sinned against thee, both I and my fathers have sinned.
1 Tim. 1.15. This is a faithful saying and worthy of all acceptation, that Christ Jesus came into the world to save sinners, of whom I am chief.

Dan. 9.4, 5, 20, 23. And I prayed unto the Lord my God and made my confession, and said, O Lord, we have sinned, and have committed iniquity and have done wickedly, and have rebelled, even by departing from thy precepts, and from thy judgments; and whilest I was speaking and praying, and eonfessing my sins and the sins of my people Israel, and presenting my supplication before the Lord my God.

Thus doth it appear, that David a Man after God's own Heart, and Daniel the beloved of the Lord; yea the holy Apostles of our Lord Jesus Christ, and many other Servants of God, even as many as wrote in his Name, thought not themselves too good, nor too holy, nor too righteous to acknowledge their Transgressions, and to confess their Sins to God Almighty, thereby acknowledging his Sovereignty over them, and the justice of his Laws and Judgments: But the Quakers like the Pharisee in the Gospel, Luke the 18.10. boast themselves of a sinless Perfection, when God knows they are but like other Men, as all Cities and Towns where they live, and with whom they deal, know right
well; tho' they like the ancient Hereticks, the Donatists and Pelagians, profess a sinless Perfection, who as I have read, concluded that a constant practice of confession did imply a constant course of sinning, to whom St. Augustin excellently answeredAug. in Ps. 99.
Confess always, for thou hast matter always to confess. He (saith St. Cyprian) is taught that he sins daily, who is taught to pray daily for the remission of his Sins [St. Cyprian] on the Lord's Prayer, who lived 250 Years after Christ.

Fox's Acts and Mon. p. 467. 468. Oh mighty Power of the most High (said Tho. Bilny that worthy Martyr) which I also, miserable Sinner, have often tasted and felt, &c. This Prayer being ended, he goes on in the next page saying, verily, when the new Testament was first set forth by Erasmus — I bought it by the providence of God, and at the first reading, as I remember, I chanced upon this sweet Sentence of St. Paul 1 Tim. 1.15. It is a true saying, and worthy of all Men to be embraced; that Christ Jesus came into the World to save sinners, of whom I am the chief and principal. This one Sentence thro' God's instruction did so exhilarate my Heart, being before wounded with the guilt of my Sin; — And therefore with all my whole Power I teach, that all Men should first acknowledge their sins and condemn them,
and afterwards Hunger and Thirst after Righteousness, &c.

Thus Reader, you may perceive that it was the practice of the Prophets, Apostles, and Martyrs, to confess their Sins to God; but read 500 of the Quakers Pharasaical Books, wherein there are divers Prayers, and you shall not find an Expression of that nature, G. Keith (who still bears that name, tho' he is separated from them and their Errors) excepted: I have George Whitehead's Book, Judgment Fixed by me; wherein there is a Prayer, containing near 5 Pages, but not a word of that nature; but like the Pharisee, applauds himself, and disdains others; saying, Thou knowest O Lord, that thou hast endued me with a Christian Spirit, and with Faith, Patience, and Rejoycing under all my Sufferings; yet thou hast endued me with a Spirit of Righteous, Judgment, Understanding, and Zeal for thy Holy Name, &c.

Babylon is fallen, is fallen, and is become the Habitations of Devils, and the Hold of every foul Spirit, and a Cage of every unclean and hateful Bird; for her Sins have reached to Heaven, and God hath remembered her Iniquity's, reward her even as she hath rewarded you, and double unto her double, according to her Works, in the Cup which she hath filled, fill to her double; rejoyce over her thou Heaven, and ye Holy Apostles and Prophets; for God hath avenged you on her, Rev. 18.2.5.6.20.

q.l: Here lye the Men; behold and view them well;
You know their Names, and where they use to dwell;
You know their Parts, you know their Fruits also:
If these be Saints; Lord whether shall we go.
If not, why should you not confession make,
And pardon beg, for Jesus Christ his sake.
Are you too proud, or do you still disdain;
Or do you say, such things with us are vain.
Behold I say, and view the Prophets well;
They did confess; the Scripture doth us tell,
Their Sins to God, and beg'd his Pardon too:
If you were humble, you would do so too.
And now observe, all you that do pass by
And notice take how coupled they do lye;
For as they live, and no confession make;
Even so they dye, which makes my heart to ake.
Yea, and lament, when that I lay to Heart,
The sad Estate, of such as do depart;
Depending on their own Righteousness,
Their own Deserts, and outside Holiness.
I say behoid, how groveling they do lye,
And cross, yea, cross, all cross to all, and why
No Man can tell, nor they a reason give;
Why they so cross should be to all that live.
Pretences great, they to Religion make,
Tho' cross to all, some think for crosness sake.
In practice cross, yea in their Fruits also;
In Manners cross, in Faith and Doctrine too.
Cross to the Saints, cross to the Prophets too;
Yea cross to all, till they themselves undo:
For who so cross as, they, who when convict,
Will still persist; their Errors not retract.
Remember then, that Babels Walls are shaken,
And her own Birds, in her own Net are taken,
As in this Cage, you may perceive right well;
Such, hateful Birds, as have no parrellel.
Who tho they boast of a sinless perfection;
As without Sin, so no need of confession:
Yet in each pair, you certainly may find,
A Bird unclean, in Body and in Mind.
This is the picture as I have often said
Of Quakerisme fairly displaid,
Drawn to the Life: I plainly do affirm
Them to convict, and not for any harm.
Why should they then so angry be and fret,
So peevish grow as if they're quite beset?
Come rouse old George, and either quite condemn
Your errors great, or else the same defend.

div.head: CHAP. IV.
Shews that the Sufferings of the Quakers do not demonstrate them to be the Church of the first Born.
div.p:
COme George, I am now come to the best spoke in your Wheel, yea, the best Flower in your Garland, and in which your chief glorying has stood; boasting over other Dissenters, who had some regard to Magistracy as God's Ordinance; and thereupon walked wisely, and submitted to the Law and Ordinance of Man for the Lord's Sake, and followed the example of good and holy Men, according to the Doctrine of Christ, who said if they persecute you in one City, flee to the next; and this St. Athanasius was sensible of
when he made his escape from the Church of Alexandria which was beset with Armed Soldiers, and for which he made a Learned and Christian Apology, see Eccles. Hist. of Socrates Schol. lib. 3. fol. 299. 300. which said Apology is Authorised by both precept and frequent Examples of the holy Prophets, Christ and his Apostles; part of which I have quoted in my Book, The painted Harlot both Stript and Whipt, &c. p. 65. 66. But Friend George I would not have you compare your Sufferings with the Sufferings of the Apostles and Martyrs, for they suffered for obeying the Doctrine of Christ Jesus, and you for your Humour. And now after all if your Sufferings, of which you so much boast (as that you gave it as one proof of your being the Church of the First Born) should prove counterfeit; what will you say? How will you come off? Where will you hide your Head? That for this 40 Years have been Writing in the defence of such horrible Errors. George you cannot go from your Post; you must either defend your Errors or retract them; and so I shall proceed to examine your Sufferings, give them their due weight, and you a full hearing; and wait your answer.

That every suffering is not persecution, all knowing Men will readily grant, and therefore it will be necessary, in the handling this point, to shew what persecution is, which according to my small Tallent, I shall do briefly thus.

Persecution, I take to consist in these two things, first, when a Man is forc'd by Authority, to decline and forsake Worshiping the true God, in that way prescribed in the Holy Scriptures; which is to renounce the Christian Faith and Worship, under pain of Imprisonment, Fines, Banishment or Death; or some other Sanguinary, or Pecuniary Pains, or Penalties: This all will grant to be Persecution, who professes and understand the Truth of the Christian Religion. And secondly, to compell Men against their Consciences, to Worship and do Sacrifice to false Gods, Idols, or Graven Images, under the like Pains and Penalties, aforesaid; this also is Persecution, to prove the first, Read Acts the 4.1, 2, 3. And as they (the Apostles) spake unto the People, the Priests, and the Captain of the Temple, and the Sadduces came upon them, being grieved that they taught the People, and Preached thro' Jesus, the Resurrection of the Dead, and they laid hands on them, and put them in hold, v. 17. And that it spread no further (said those Persecutors) among the People; let us straitly threaten them, that they speak henceforth to no Man in this Name, cap. 5.28, 29, 30. Did not we straitly command you, that you should not Teach in this Name, and behold you have fill'd Jerusalem with your Doctrine; and intend to bring this Man's Blood upon us. Then Peter and the other Apostles answered and said; we ought to obey God rather than Men. The God of our Fathers, raised up
Jesus, whom ye slew and hanged on a Tree; him hath God exalted with his right hand, to be a Prince and a Saviour, to give Repentance to Israel and forgiveness of Sins, &c. This then is a good warrant, for all Christian Ministers to maintain their Christian Faith and Confession as God shall enable them, even to the death, and in such cases, we ought to obey God rather than Man.

And the second, being a Negative, suffering for the Profession and Confession of the Christian Faith is like unto the first, viz. 'tis better to obey God who hath commanded us to abstain from Idols; and not to fall down and worship graven Images; then to violate our Faith, by a Sinful Compliance. And in this case also are we justified by the Warrant and Command of God, Recorded in the Holy Scriptures, as well as by the constant and laudable Practice of the Primitive Christians, under the Ten Persecutions, as well as under papal unscriptural Impositions.

But whether the Quakers Sufferings, come under either of these Heads; ought to be duly considered; and that by themselves, as well as others: If they say yea; I then demand an Instance for this Forty six Years, the time of their Date; to shew me a Warrant, under the Hand and Seal of any one Justice of Peace, who committed any one, or more of them, for Preaching through Jesus the Resurrection of the Dead. I will not deny, but some of them have been committed for Preaching their
Light, in opposition to Jesus, denying the Resurrection of the Dead: But this is no Persecution, this is only Prosecution against Offenders, in defence of the Christian Faith; which yet ought to be done, with great care and tenderness, and by Laws suitable to the Nature of the Offence; having always a regard to the sincerity of the Offenders, who have adhered to wrong Notions, and thereby became Captives to mistaken Principles.

Obj. But if the Quakers shall object, that there have been Laws made by our Christian Kings and Parliaments; which they cannot for Conscience sake obey actively, and to suffer for their Non-submission. This is Persecution: I answer not so; for then the Quakers themselves, we shall find Persecutors, which they will be loath to acknowledg. For Instance, In Pensilvania, there has happen'd a Religious Difference amongst the Quakers: The Foxonian Quakers, having the Government under the Honourable William Penn, (as his Title there is; how much soever, they are against Titles of Honour in England) Well, So it fell out, that these Governing Quakers, made certain Laws against the Dissenting Quakers: The Dissenting Quakers, they do complain of hard usage; they Print and Disperse this Complaint. The Foxonian Quakers, they take this as an Affront to the Government. They Issue out their Warrant, to apprehend a Printer and a Publisher of this their Complaint: A Copy of which Warrant,
is as followeth, viz.

Whereas, William Bradford Printer, and John Macomb Taylor, being brought before us, upon an Information, of Publishing, Uttering, and spreading a Malicious and Seditious Paper; Intituled, An Appeal from the 28 Judges, to the Spirit of Truth, Tending to the Disturbing of the Peace, and Subversion of the present Government. And the said Persons, being required to give security to answer it at the next Court; but they refusing so to do: These are therefore by the King and Queen's Authority, and our Proprietors Name; to require you to take into your Custody, the Bodies of William Bradford and John Macomb, and them safely to keep, till they shall be discharged, by due course of Law; whereof, fail not at your Peril: And for your so doing, this shall be your sufficient Warrant, given under our Hands and Seals,

postscript.p: To John White, Sheriff of Phyladelphia, or his Deputy.

div.p:
Now Reader, observe the Crime, viz. For Printing An Appeal from 28 Judges, [viz. Quakers, who at their Meeting, had not dealt fairly by those two Prisoners their Friends, at least they thought so] to the Spirit of Truth; and compare the Severity, especially at their Tryal; and see whether these governing Quakers
have not exceeded all the Justices of the Peace in England: For how do the Quakers in England print, publish, and disperse Papers and printed Books, and send them not only throughout England and Wales, but beyond the Sea, which not only condemn the Ministry and Doctrine of the Church of England, but throw contempt on the Magistrates, and censure their very Acts of Parliament as Antichristian, to the great scandal of the English Government, both in Church and State, and yet they are let alone to do what they please: And notwithstanding all this Indulgence, what complaints we have from their yearly Meetings of persecution, to the dishonour of the Christian Magistracy; and in p. 13. of the said Tryals, I find that one Peter Boss was Indicted for calling Sam. Jennings a Quaker Justice, a Magisterial Officer, which as G. Keith expounded it, signifies only Master like, and yet both Quakers; whilest W. Penn at his Tryal Sept. 1670. in open Court said to the Lord Mayor of the famous City of London, viz. but above all, Dissenters had little reason to have expected that Boarish Fierceness from the Mayor of London, when they consider his eager prosecution of the King's Party under Cromwell's Government, as thinking he could never give too great a Testimony of his Loyalty to that new Instrument, which makes the old saying true, that one Runagado is worse than 3 Turks, &c.

I say considering the station of the Lord Mayor of London, to be thus abused, and to put up such a base dishonourable and scandalous Affront: It did shew more patience and forbearance, than the Quakers Justices themselves can bear, now in place of Authority, as well as shew the Temper of a pragmatical Quaker, W. Penn who then and there call'd the Indictments detestable Juggles, Romance Indictments; and why forsooth? because the form of the Indictment contained more than the Witnesses could prove: Yet now the Quakers are led by their Light to go to Law; they can frame as detestable Juggles in their Indictments, as any People whatsoever; witness their Indictment against my self, for printing unlicensed, baring Date the 9th. of October, 1693. viz. That Fra. Bugg late of London Yeoman, being a Person of an unquiet and turbulent disposition; devising, practising, and intending falsly, unlawfully, seditiously and maliciously, G. W. &c. As also to move, stir up, and cause Discords, Tumults, and miserable Slaughters, &c. but to manifest the Quakers base and false pretences, even of this nature, would require a Book by it self, and now to the matter again, viz.

I shall next present the World with the heads of a Book presented to the King and Parliament, Printed Anno. 1664. thus entitituled, viz. For the King and both Houses of Parliament; being a Declaration of the
present Sufferings of the people of God call'd Quakers, &c. Next I shall collect some of the chief heads of their Suffering case, and then consider how far it affects the Quakers, as to persecution; and if it be persecution, how much it amounts to, as proof that they are the Church of the First Born, as G. Whitehead says in his Apostate Incendiary p. 4 viz. And as for our confessing that we are the Church of the First Born, let our Doctrine, Testimony, Lives and Sufferings bear witness, &c. Three of their principal things by which the Quakers Church would prove her self the true Church of Christ, the Elect People of God, even the Church of the First Born, I have gone thro', and now I am upon the Suffering Head, viz.
1. We suffer, because we cannot pay Tythes.
2. We suffer, because we cannot pay the Clarks wages, that turns up the Hour-glass.
3. We suffer, because we do not go to the Steeple-house.
4. We suffer, because we set open our Shops on Fast days.
5. We suffer, because we do not put off our Hats.
6. We suffer, because we say Thee and Thou to particular Persons.
7. We suffer, because we do not follow the national Worship.
8. We suffer, because we do not follow the World's fellowship.
9. We suffer, because we cannot Sing nor Repair the Church.
10. We suffer, because we speak in the Synagogue, Temple, or Steeple-houses.
11. We suffer, because we cannot Swear.
12. We suffer, because we meet together to worship God.
13. We suffer, because we deny all Games, Sports, and Plays, costly Apparel, powdered Hair, &c.
14. We suffer, because many Women speak abroad.

Come G. W. I have taken a List of your Sufferings, but before I come to examine whether your Sufferings be persecution, and thereby merit your Title of being the Church of the First Born; I shall let the World see that you over value your Sufferings, to a degree of Blasphemy; and that shall be my Text or Subject matter to compare your Sufferings, see E. Burrow's Works p. 275. It plainly appeareth, that the Sufferings of the People of God (called Quakers) in this Age, is greater Suffering and more Ʋnjust, than in the days of Christ, or his Apostles, or in any time since. What was done to Christ or his Apostles, was chiefly done by a Law; and in great part by the due execution of a Law; and hereby it appears the Suffering to be more unjust; because what the Persecutors of old time did to the People of God, they did by a Law, and by the due Execution of a Law: But now many are caused to suffer
deeply whom the Transgression of no Law, good or bad can be charged against; and others suffer without the due execution of a Law, &c.

Come G. W. do you not blush, are you not ashamed to see your Sufferings valued above the Sufferings of Christ, his Apostles, and all his Martyrs since? What horrid Blasphemy is this Quaker Church guilty of? Come serious George I will ask you some Questions, and expect your answer, Yea or Nay. 1. Whether the Sufferings of the Quakers be greater than the Sufferings of Christ, his Apostles, Martyrs and Confessors. 2. Are the Sufferings of the Quakers more unjust, than the Sufferings of Christ, his Apostles and Martyrs. 3. Was the Sufferings, Murder and Cruelty, inflicted upon Christ his Apostles and Martyrs, chiefly done by a Law. 4. By what Law did the Jews and Heathens execute their Cruelty upon Christ, his Apostles and Prophets. 5. Was the said Laws of the Jews and Heathens duly executed upon Christ, his Apostles and Martyrs, as your Doctors Teach; Answer me plainly to all the 5 Questions. Again, I ask you G. W. Whether on second Thoughts you will say yea, and so justifie Burrows? Or nay, and so condemn the Quakers Doctrine which teach such horrible Blasphemy, and that by your approbation. Besides George, the Apostles Suffered for Preaching, thro' Jesus, the Resurrection of the dead, and Remission of Sins in his Name: But the Quakers suffer for
the contrary, viz. for Preaching from their Light within against what Jesus Christ commanded: Go Baptize, &c. Do this in remembrance of me, &c. Pray after this manner.— Forgive us our sins, as we forgive them that trespass against us: And this alters the case very much: The Apostles and Martyrs Suffered, who Preached and Taught in the Name of Jesus, who wrought Miracles in the Name of Jesus, this was persecution. But the Quakers Suffer, who Teach in their own Name, and thereby make void the Commands of Christ Jesus, under pretence of their Light within, and work Miracles (as they call them) in their own Name: This indeed may be Suffering, but not Persecution, and so no evidence of the Quakers being the Church of the First Born. And now I shall proceed to the particular cases of the Quakers Sufferings, being 14 in number as abovetold.
1. We suffer because we cannot pay Tythes to the covetous Priests and Antichristian Impropriators.

Answer, why then do you not pay your Tythes, and live in subjection to the Laws of the Land according to the Apostles Doctrine? who said, be subject to every ordinance of Man for the Lords sake. But this is not all, you the Leaders of the Quakers do not only disobey the Law of the Land your selves, but you hold your yearly Meetings in London, a week or Ten days together; and there you make Laws, Orders and Decrees, against the
known Laws made at Westminster, and therein, and thereby absolve the King's Subjects of their obedience, so far as they adhere to you as the higher Powers: And for this your presumption I impeached your yearly Meeting 1693. in these words.

p.q: The Quakers yearly Meeting, or Convocation impeached, on the behalf of the Canons of England, viz. That Geo. Whitehead and his Brethren, at a Convocation begun at London the 5th. of May, 1693. (ending the 8th. day of the same Month) did contrive, make and promulgate several Constitutions and Canons Ecclesiastical; containing in them divers Matters and Things, contrary to the Fundamental Laws of the Realm; against the King's Prerogative, against the Rights of Parliaments, against the Property of the Subject; and Matters tending to Sedition, and of dangerous consequence.

div.p:
This was the Impeachment, and there was great reason for it; one Instance I may recite, viz. Whereas, there was an Act of Parliament, made since His Present Majesties coming to the Crown, for Exempting His Majesties Protestant Subjects, Dissenting from the Church of England, from the Penalty's of certain Laws, &c. In which Act, there is one Clause, which the Quakers did not like; but soon after, at their High Court, at Devonshire-house, Repealed the same, what in them lay, and Absolved the King's Subjects from their Obedience; to the same, as anon will appear: But first, the said Clause, viz. Provided alway,
that nothing herein contained, shall be construed, to exempt any of the Persons aforesaid, from paying of Tythes, or other Parochial Duty s, or any other Duty's, to the Church or Minister; nor from any Prosecution, in any Ecclesiastical Court, or elsewhere for the same, &c.

I say this Clause, in the Act of Parliament, did not suit with the Quakers Light; and they were moved to Repeal it, and what in them lay to make it void; both by their Printed Laws, directed to all their Monthly and Quarterly Meetings, in England and Wales, and elsewhere; concerning Tythes and Repairs of Churches; as also by their Practice.

The Quakers Yearly Epistle, &c. p. 1. And therefore, that all due care be taken, against the Grand Oppression, and Antichristian Yoke of Tythes, that our Christian Testimony born, and greatly suffered for, be faithfully maintained against them, in all Respects; and against Steeple-houses-Rates and Lays; as also against the Burden and Imposition of Oaths.

p.q:
—That Friends, at all there Monthly and Quarterly Meetings, be reminded to call for the Records of the Sufferings of Friends; to see that they be duly gathered, truly entered and kept, and accordingly sent up [to London] as hath been often advised; both of what Tythes, &c. are pretended to be due, and for how long a time, and the time when taken, and by, and for whom, and what Goods are taken, and the value thereof; as
well of those not exceeding, as them exceeding the Summ or Quantities [of Tythes] demanded (it being a Suffering in both, for Truth's sake) they being in these particulars found defective and imperfect in divers Country's; which is an Obstruction to the General Record of Friends Sufferings, &c.

div.p: Come George Whitehead, my old Antagonist, you see my Impeachment, and you may see the reason of it. First, The Parliament have provided in their Act; that nothing therein shall be construed, to exempt the Quakers from payment of their Tythes, Church Dues, and Repairing the Churches: This was done, by King, Lords and Commons, Assembled in Parliament, holden at Westminster: But the Quakers at their Convocation, not Legally called, nor by Law permitted; yet they being set at Devonshire-house, they enact; That all due care be taken against that Grand Oppression, and Antichristian Yoak, the payment of Tythes, against the paying to Church Wardens Rates, &c.

And when any do Suffer, though no more than their Neighbours; yet a Record thereof must be taken, and brought up to London, in order to Print it; and thereby to expose the Magistrates and Legislators, as a Tribe of Antichristian Persecutors, when there Holy Chronicle came forth, mentioned, in Judas and the Jews, &c. p. 58. and there Rejoynder, p. 410. Saying, our Faithful Chronicles, of the Bloody Tragedies of that Professing Generation, will tell future Ages other things, &c.
viz. What bitter times of sore Persecution, there was, during the Reign of His Present Majesty, K.W. III. which being duly considered, renders them ungratful, with a witness: Forgetting that in there Suffering, for non-payment of Tythes; they do not suffer for keeping the Commands of God, the Precepts of Christ, or the Apostles; but only for keeping the Command of George Fox, the first Founder of Quakerism.
2. We suffer, because we cannot pay the Clarks, that turn up the Hour-glass.

Well, what have you suffered, for not paying the Clark his Wages: I have examined your Book, stiled, The Record of Sufferings, &c. Where in p. 24. under this Title; Clarks Wages, and repairing of Steeple houses. I have read near two Pages, and find nothing suffered, for non-payment of Clarks Wages; but at the end, it concludes thus: All these Summs, was taken for the Repairing of Steeple-houses. Then I was at a loss, where to find Sufferings on that account; worth presenting the King and Parliament; at least, with much searching in p. 10. 11. I find that William Tiplady, Robert Tiplady, and Robert Storehouse, for Clarks Wages had taken from them, as many Goods, as themselves prised them worth 17 s. 8 d. and more I could not find; Oh! wonderful, that People should so magnifie their Sufferings, as to think 17 s. 8 d. worth troubling the King and Parliament: And yet if they think thereby, to merit the Title of being The Church of the First born; who can blame them:
But I take this Vain Boasting of Suffering, for a great sign of the contrary.
3. We suffer, because we do not go to the Steeple-house.
Answer, Suffer; but what did you suffer? And what were you enjoyned to come for? Was it to Worship a false God; or the true God, in a false way; for otherwise, every Suffering, is not Persecution?
4. We suffer, because we set open our Shops on Fast-days.
Answer, The more shame for you? Who will hazard your Liberty and Peace, for the observing George Fox's Commandments.

But since 'tis no Command of God, that you observe in the keeping your Shop open on Fast-days; but George Fox's Command, 'tis not Persecution: However, many begin to grow wiser now; and shut up there Shops, in Submission to the Government: And they begin to trample under foot, the Commands of that Imposter Fox.
5. We suffer, because we say thee and thou to a single Person.

Answer, If you can shew any Warrant, under the Hand and Seal of any Justice of Peace, that you suffered purely for that; either Imprisonment, Banishment, or spoiling of Goods. I will say, the Justice did not well; yet I cannot think it Persecution: But if you have been laughed at, for your singularity therein; you ought to be content, and never tell the King and Parliament of it.
6. We suffer, because we do not put off our Hats to our Superiors.

Answer, So did Ignatius Loyola; (as Maffejus and Orlandinus testifie) by which, saith a Learned Author (in his Book, A Discourse, concerning the Idolatry practised in the Church of Rome.) p. 273. We understand, who was the first Founder of that Fanatick Sect amongst us, [the Quakers] Upon this, the Commander severely rebuked the Souldiers, for bringing a Mad-man before him; who being thereat enraged, whipt him soundly, and let him go, &c. and p. 282. Yet any one, who compares them (i. e. Quakers) would imagin (saith my Author) the Life of Ignatius, had been their great Exampler: I know not whether any of that Innocent and Religious Order of the Jesuits, had any hand of forming this New Society among us; (as hath been frequently suggested) but if one may guess the Father by the Child's Likeness; Ignatius Loyola, the Founder of the Jesuits, was at least the Grandfather of the Quakers.

Come George Whitehead, you see Ignatius Loyola was soundly whipt; and doubtless, he reckoned it a Suffering; for the Jesuits, like the Quakers, love to magnifie there Sufferings: And I do think, some of you may have met with alike Suffering, for the like cause: And you may Record it too, if you please; but still 'tis no Persecution, and cannot merit your Title to the Church of the First Born: yet if you please, it may help you into the Society of the Jesuits, and you may plead Antiquity, to strengthen the Commandment of George
Fox. Well, but if you did suffer, as you tell the King and Parliament; I think you had but your just Desert; you pretend, you cannot put off your Hat for Conscience sake to your Superiors? Why then do you compel your Inferiors to stand bare headed before you in your Houses and Shops; this is such a piece of Hypocrisie, that Ignatius Loyola your Grandsire, could not well exceed: Yet this is your practice, I know it, and can prove what I say, from many Instances. And indeed, it was the first piece of Hypocrisie that I found amongst you, when I was a Quaker: And the very first thing, that gave me Offence; and I as early shew'd my dislike thereof; and Wrote a Letter to Samuel Cater, to the Yearly Meeting, that it might be remedied; which Letter, gave great offence; and I was sent for, by G. Barnadiston; and I did before him and others, maintain it to be a great piece of Hypocrisie; and said, we might as well put off our Hats to our Superiors, as require it of our Inferiors: And from that time, I was by some few of that Ambitious sort of Teachers; not looked upon to be a right ground fast Quaker. Thus it pleased God; to bring Good to me, out of your Evil; and that it may appear, how early I withstood some Errors amongst the Quakers: I may recite the said Letter, to Samuel Cater.

body.head: To Samuel Cater, these.
body.p:
These are to open my Mind to thee, touching our Friends forcing their
Apprentices to stand bare-headed before them [in their Houses and Shops] and my request to thee is to lay it before Friends, at the yearly Meeting, whether we ought to impose that on our Servants, which many of us, when Apprentices, could not bear; and having of late heard it pleaded for, and seen it practised, I Testified against it; and whereas 'tis objected, that good Friends practice it; I Answer, if so, why then may not we put off our Hats to the King, and plead that he is Master and chief Governour over the whole Family of England. Moreover our Apprentices who succeed us, may in the next Age say, as for our Masters they respected not the persons of Princes, nor any Court of Judicature, but were zealous for their Religion, often professing that God respected neither Time, Place, nor Person; but they themselves no sooner came into their Houses or Shops, where they were chief Governours, but off we must put our Hats, and before them stand bare-headed; they pleaded it would give offence to the World: So let us turn our backs upon them and their Religion too; since by their practice they unsay their sayings, building again what they once destroyed, &c.

div.p:
Thus G. W. I leave you with your Suffering on this account: You see you are not the First: You now know your exampler, and
whose practice you follow, and whose Commandment [G. F.'s] you obey; but remember 'tis an infallible proof of a deceitful practice in requiring respect from your inferiors, and refusing the same to your superiors. The 7 8 and 9th. particular cases being the same with the 3d. I referr to the 3d. Answer.
10. We suffer, because we speak in the Synagogue, Temple or Steeple-house.

Ans. Suffer, how do you mean Suffer? What would you have liberty to disturb all publick Preachers by your outragious clamors and troublesome behaviour, without regard to Law, Rule or Government, and meet with no curb nor restraint? Why may not every mad distracted Person, who disturbs the publick Peace, and meets with a sutable reward, complain of suffering as well as you? But since your Suffering have taught you better manners, I shall not long insist on this Head; I mean taught you to leave of that turbulent practice which you learnt of G. Fox, as appears by his Journal.
11. We suffer, because we cannot Swear.

Ans. I grant some of the Hearers may Suffer who are sincere: But for the Leaders and many of your Elders, they can Swear, and have for many years taken an Oath to save themselves, as the Courts of Chancery, and other Courts sufficiently declare; and for which practice amongst them, notwithstanding their pretence to the contrary, I will give you an instance even of thy self, dear George,
who have Preached a Thousand times against it, and to save thy Bacon, can now do it; and tho' I have printed it and re-printed it; yet thou hast not the confidence to deny it; but if you should, your own Attorney and Mr. Damell's Attorney; whose names I have, both will witness it; nay the whole Court present, took such notice of it, that thou must have a Face of brass to deny it. G. Whitehead having a Bill exhibited against him, by Tho. Damell and Elizabeth his Wife, in the Lord Mayor's Court in London, April the 9th. 1695. The said Oath follows in these words.

☞ You [G.W.] do Swear, that so much of this your Answer as you set forth, to be of your own knowledge, to be certain and true; and so much thereof as you set forth to be by Relation of others, you do believe to be true, so help you God.

This Oath, in open Court, was read to G. Whitehead, the Book put to his Mouth; he submitted to it without gainsaying, and it was accepted by the Court for an Oath, and it stands upon Record, as hundreds more so taken do, in that and other Courts. What cause then have the Quakers thus to complain, and pretend Conscience where they make none? I do not charge this as an evil in it self, any more than to take the solemn Attestation prescribed them by the Parliament; for they both call God to witness to the truth of what they say: But the Deceit and Hypocrisy lies in pretending Conscience, and to make the World believe
they cannot Swear, when 'tis manifest the same Men, nay, the most noted, G. Whitehead for one can Swear in a corner privately. So that this kind of Suffering being void of sincerity, does not amount to a proof that the Quakers are the Church of the First Born.
12. We suffer, because we meet together to worship God.

Ans. This I do deny, on behalf of the Magistrates; I never knew such a Law made in England to prevent any from Meeting to worship God, and shall, until the Quakers can shew me such a Law which I never heard of nor saw: Indeed I do know that in the 22 years of King Charles II. there was an Act of Parliament entituled an Act to prevent and suppress Seditious Conventicles, in which it was said, be it Enacted by, &c. That if any Person of the Age of 16 years and upwards, being a Subject of this Realm, at any time after the 10th. day of May next, shall be present at any Assembly, &c. under colour or pretence of any exercise of Religion, in other manner then according to the Liturgy and Practice of the Church of England, &c. at which there shall be five Persons or more Assembled together, over and besides those of the same Houshold, &c.

I grant, that if any did transgress this Law, they did incurr certain penalties: But notwithstanding, the Government was not chargable with the scandalous Crime of Persecution: Forasmuch as this Law did not hinder Men
from worshiping the true God in the way he has prescribed, who said, Wherever 2 or 3 are gathered together in my Name, I am in the midst; nor doth it compel Men to do Sacrifice to Idols or graven Images, the works of Mens Hands.

And 2dly. In regard it is a written Law, and in our Mother Tongue that all may read it, and see both the danger, and how to prevent it; and pay their obedience to the Magistrates and Ministers of it, who bear not the Sword in vain.

Again 3dly. This Law allowed a moderate Tolleration, for four Persons might meet besides those of the Family, which probably might be ten or fifteen more, which had been a tollerable Meeting, and such as the Martyrs would have been glad of. And I am fully perswaded, that had the Quakers regarded the Law, and reverenced the Magistratical Power, and met together modestly, with a purpose only to pray to God, expound a Chapter, and exhort each other to a pious Life; if it had so happen'd, that now and then there had happen'd to be ten or twenty more than the Law in strictness allowed; That the Magistrates would, for peace sake, have born it: [And altho' I, when a Quaker, felt the Rod of Correction for my Stubborness; for in that case, both for blind Zeal and Suffering for the same, I was not behind my equals:] And my Reason is, that since I came to be perswaded I ought to submit to Magistracy, as God's Ordinance,
I have had no one thing imposed upon me that was a scruple to my Conscience to perform. But when the Magistrates saw, that the Quakers, above all People, took no notice of the Law, nor the Power of the Magistrates; but in Scorn and Contempt, trampled under foot all Authority, in Kings, Lords, and Commons; in Judges, Justices, and all Inferior Officers, according to their Principles, in George Foxes Book, News coming up, &c. p. 18. 19. Dreadful is the Lord, who is coming to Execute true Judgment, upon all you Judges; and to change all your Laws, the Kings, all your Rulers must down, and all your Underling Officers, which have been as the Arms of this great Tree; all your Branches must be cut down; so you must be cut down with the same Power that cut down the King, whose Family, was a Nursery for Papists, and for Bishops, which held up Rails, Alters, &c. Woe! woe! is coming upon you all. The same Teachers are standing, that was in the time of the King, and in the time of the Bishops; and such as take Tythes; the true Prophets of the Lord cried against them then, and the Lord hath raised up his Prophets to cry against them, now as then; and against you Judges and Justices, which hath held them up, and maintain'd them with your Law, you must both be tormented together, Beast, and false Prophets: The Lord God will pour out his Plagues upon you; the
Lord of Hosts hath spoken it: And except you Repent, you shall all likewise perish and be consumed, as the King was, p. 20. Sing all ye Saints and Rejoyce; clap your Hands and be glad; for the Lord Jehovah will Reign, and the Government shall be taken from you, pretended Rulers, Judges and Justices, Lawyers and Constables: All this Tree must be Cut down; and Jesus Christ [in us] will Rule alone, &c.

I say, when the Magistrates saw their Contempt of Government, and understood that their chief Work in their Meetings, as well as Writings, was to lower their Power, to reproach the Ministers, and Preach against all Instituted Religion; comparing the Magistrates, to Pharaoh, Nebuchadnezzar, Darius &c. And the Clergy, to Witches, Devils, Conjurers, Thieves, Robbers, greedy Dogs, &c. And the Bible, a Dead Letter; Death, Dust, Beastly Ware, Serpents Meat, &c. And the Sacraments of Baptisme, and the Lords Supper, were no Ordinances of God; but Institutions of the Whore of Rome, and the Practice of them; Idolatry, and no part of the Worship of God, and the like Blasphemies; and also remembring whence they first sprung to wit, out of the Dregs of the People: As Ranters, Levellers, and other Latitudinarians. And from thence, knowing their Principles to be Antimonarchical; as well as Antimagistratical: This and the like; (too much to mention here) put the Magistrates upon Exerting
their Power, not in Persecution; but in Prosecuting Wilful and Obstinate Offenders, in defence of the Church and State; at the Foundation of which, the Quakers Principles and Practices seem to strike: But as they served the Act, made for the Payment of Tythes, Church Dues, &c. Mentioned in the Answer to the first of these 14 Particulars; they served this; for they from their Yearly Meeting, gave forth their Law, which did virtually (respecting the Quakers, though not verbally) repeal this Act also; and Absolv'd the King's Subject from their Active Obedience: And when this would not do; their Teachers Travelled from East to West, from North to South, sending out their Mandates, to have the People come far and near; that so they might have great and large Meetings, to vend their Pestilential Doctrine, above-told. And that I may not be thought to Impose upon my Reader; I will give for each of these their Practices, single Instances.
The first shall be that Edict from their yearly Meeting, which is as followeth, viz.

div.head: Concerning our open Testimony, by publick Meetings, in Times of Sufferings, the 27th. of the 3d. Month, 1675.
div.p:
That as it hath been our Care and Practice from the beginning, that an open Testimony for the Lord should be born, and a
publick Standard for Truth and Righteousness upheld in the Power and Spirit of God, by our open and known Meetings; against the Spirit of Persecution, that in all Ages hath sought to lay Wast God's Heritage; and that only through Faithfulness, Constancy, and Patience, Victory hath been, and is obtained. So it is our Advice and Judgment, that all Friends, gathered in the Name of Jesus, keep up those publick Testimonies in their respective Places; and not forsake, decline, or remove their publick Assemblies, because of Times of Sufferings, as worldly, fearfull, and politick Professors have done, because of Informers and the like Persecutors: For such practices are not consistent with the Nobility of the Truth, and therefore not to be owned in the Churches of Christ.

closer.signed:
Subscribed by us
William Penn.
G. Whitehead.
Stephen Crispe.
and others.

div.p: The next Instance shall be from one of their publick Teachers, which is as followeth, viz.

body.head: This for Joshua Banks.
body.p:
By this thou may'st know, that God-willing, Jonathan Johnson and I do intend to be at Mildenhall-Meeting the next First Day, being the 17th Instant, and shall be glad Friends generally may know thereof, that we may
have a good Large Meeting; I mean Friends that are a far off in the Country.

div.p: To these let me add one Instance more by a Letter sent to my self, to appoint a Meeting for George Whitehead; but with this caution, not to mention his name, for that did not sute his interest; no, he being one of the cowardly, fearful, and politick Professors; He by the said yearly Edict caution'd us not to be, which being spoken fully too in my Book, The painted Harlot both Stript and Whipt, &c. p. 15. 16. I shall say little of it hear more than mention it, viz.

body.head: For Fra. Bugg, these.
body.p: This is to acquaint thee that George Whitehead is now here, and doth purpose to be at your Meeting, at Mildenhall, the next 5th. day (i. e. the 27th. Instant) and therefore desires that Friends may be together by the 11th. Hour at farthest: Thou need'st not make use of his Name to any particularly, but may'st acquaint them with a Friend's intention to be with them upon the day and time aforesaid; so with George Whitehead's, and all our dear loves to Thee and thy Wife, I Rest thy dear Friend.

div.p:
From all which 'tis observable, that first by their yearly Edicts they set aside null, and
make void Acts of Parliament, when not suting their design, which appears to lay Wast the Christian Religion, as also that their Teachers in their Travels too and fro, send out their Mandates or Summons to gather the people together round the County; yea, saith R. Sandiland Friends a far off, no matter what the Law says: For as G. Fox said in Ireland when the Inn-keeper told him the Council had granted forth Warrants to apprehend him; What do you tell me (said Fox) of their Warrants against me? If there were a Cart load of them I do not heed them. Fox's Journal p. 278.

In like manner their Teachers, writing after his Copy, heed not a Cart load of Laws, but in contempt of them, write frequently to have them meet in great Numbers to come from far and near to confront the Government; yea, G. Whitehead's intimation was like himself, the people must meet, but with whom they must not know, whether a Jesuit or a Monk; the hour is set, they must not fail; and when the Meeting is over, let the Justices, Informers, and the poor deluded Quakers shift together. It would require a Volumn to set forth the covetous Practices, and cunning Politicks, of these Ring-leaders.

But as I have given 2 or 3 Instances of the Quakers joynt Testimony against their peoples obedience to the Laws of the Land; and also of their Teachers, in their Travels too and fro to seduce the people, not only from the Christian Religion, but from their Allegiance to
their Governors, as appears from plain matter of fact. So it will not be amiss to give one Instance of their Teachers deceitful practice, whereby they blind the World, delude their Hearers, and mis-represent the Acts and Deeds of the Christian Magistrates; First to this, but more especially to the next Generation, by their faithful Chronicle so often mentioned: And that the World may know they have a design to bring out a Volumn of their Sufferings in the nature of the Book of Martyrs. I will give some few manifest Tokens of it, or there can be none given; and also a Sample of their pretended Sufferings of which they so much Glory, as that it is a Sign they are the Church of the First-born, viz.

1. Judas and the Jews, &c. p. 41. Our faithful Chronicles of the bloody Tragedies of that professing Generation, will tell Future Ages other things, &c. I take this to be a fair Item of what they intend: But above all I commend their Politicks, in staying, before they produce it till the next Age, when none will be alive to detect their Falacies; 'tis too like George Fox, who published his counterfeit Miracles 20 years after he pretended to have wrought them, as his Journal manifests. But again,

2. A Rejoynder, &c. p. 410. New provocations may give fresh occasion for their History to come abroad to the Nation more compendiously than ever, &c. These two Items
we have had, more than 20 years since, and yet no compendious History of their sore Persecutions is yet come forth, though many would be glad to see it: But hold, 'tis not to tell us, but future Ages, I commend them, that's most safe for Hypocrites. I also Remember, that about the year 1672 or 1673 I was chosen to go up to London about our Sufferings, and then I heard several eager to have it come forth, others that had more wit in their Anger sa d nay, but let it alone still. But again,

3. The Anarchy of the Ranters, &c. printed 1676. p. 42. That as through our faithful Testimony in the hand of the Lord, that Antichristian and Apostatised Generation, the National Ministry hath received a deadly Blow, by our discovering and witnessing against their forced Maintenance and Tythes, against which we have Testified by many cruel Sufferings of all kinds; as our Chronicles shall make known to Generations to come: So that their Kingdom in the Hearts of Thousands begins to Totter and loose its Strength, and shall assuredly Fall to the Ground, through Truth's prevailing in the Earth. So on the other hand, do we by coming to Truth and Righteousness, and Innocency, weaken the Strength of their Kingdom, who judge for Rewards, as well as such that preach for Hire: And — the Nations shall come to be eased of and disburthened of that deceitful Tribe of Lawyers, as well as Priests, &c.

I think, this Third Stroak, has struck the Nail to the head; it need not be Paraphrased upon: It was in 76; and by their Learned Barklay: Yet I shall give the World a fresher Instance, even in 1693. when (one would think) the Quakers had no cause to complain of Persecution; but all is one: They love to talk of their Sufferings, and as well to magnifie them; they are still at work, like Moles under ground. They told us, in the Epistle prefixt to Burrow's Works, viz. First of all, our Mouths were opened, and our Spirit filled with Indignation against the Priests and Teachers, and with them, and against them. We first began to War, as the Fountain of all Wickedness; the Issue of Prophaneness: And this was the first Work we entered upon; to thresh down the Deceivers, and lay them open; that all People might see their Shame, and come from them, &c. And as they began, so they continue; they are no Changelings. 'Tis the Alpha and Omega of their Religion. George Whitehead, uses to call for better Tools than I am; and indeed, I think 'tis high time for them to appear; for I own my self too weak for this great Work; to discover and lay open the most Formidable Heresie that ever appear'd, since the dayes of Simon Magus. I grant there are but few see the Quakers, and fewer that take notice of them, and still fewer that understand the danger of their undermining Principles: But if any be desirous to make a search into this matter, I
refer them to two Books, viz. The Snake in the Grass, &c. and Satan Disrob'd, &c. and George Keith's Labours. And so I proceed to my 4th. and last Instance on this Head.

4. The Quakers Yearly Epistle, to all the Monthly and Quarterly Meetings, in England and Wales, and else where. Printed, 1693. p. 1. And therefore, that all due and Godly Care be taken, against the Grand Oppression, and Antichristian Yoke of Tythes; that our Testimony, born and greatly suffered for, be faithfully maintained against them in all respects; and against Steeple-house-rates: That Friends, in all their Monthly and Quarterly Meetings, be reminded, to call for the Records of Friends Sufferings; to see that they be duly gathered, truly entered and kept, and accordingly sent up to [London] as hath been often advised; both of what Tythes are pretended to be due, and for how long a time, and the time when taken; [by Distress for non payment] and the value thereof, as well of those not exceeding, as those exceeding the summs or quantities demanded, it being a Suffering in both for Truth's sake, they [the said Monthly and Quarterly Meetings] being in these particulars found defective, and imperfect in divers Counties, which is an Obstruction of the general Records of Friends Sufferings. And therefore the Monthly and Quarterly Meetings are desired to take more care for the future; that all Friends Sufferings, for Truth's sake, may be brought
up (to London) as full and compleat, in all Respects, as possible may be, &c.

Reader, in these four Instances you have the Heart of Quakerism, and the Hands and Pens of W. Penn, R. Barkly, G. Whitehead and the Heads of the Gang: You see their design from first to last, and the continuance of it. And now let me give you an Instance of one of their Teachers Deceit and his pretended Suffering, I mean Sam. Cater, I do not mean his Suffering the loss of his Kettle, worth (as himself said five Shillings) for a fine of ten-pence for non payment of Tythes, as in their Book, The Record of Sufferings, &c. p. 5. But whether the said Kettle was return'd I cannot tell; no I do not mean that, I mean his Suffering Twenty Pounds, for preaching in Norfolk, I would say his pretence so to suffer. The case is this.

Sam. Cater of Little-port in the Isle of Ely, being at a Meeting in Phakenham in Norfolk, July 1670. Was convicted for Preaching, and Fined Twenty Pounds, by Sir Christopher Colthorp; and the Records of conviction was sent to Thomas March, John Laney, and Thomas Hitch Esquires, Justices of the Peace for the Isle of Ely; who, according to Law, Issued out their Warrants for Distress and Sale of Sam. Cater's Goods. Well, the Constable Executed their Warrant, distrained his Goods, Timber, and other Lumber to the value of Twenty Pounds, but left them all in Sam's Possession, at least under his Wall in
the Streets side; and some time after a calm happen'd, and the Constable being a moderate Man, did not sell a peny-worth, but return'd all and every thing so distrain'd to Sam. again, and thus ended this Man's most cruel Suffering, for which he made such a lamentable Cry, as afterwards you shall here.

Well, Sam. being distrain'd, he presently came to our Quarterly Meeting, where I was then Recorder, and brings me the state of his case, and by his direction I Recorded as followeth, viz. See their Quarterly Book.

p.q: Samuel Cater, for being at a Meeting at Phakenham in Norfolk, on the 4th. Day of the 5th. Month called July, Anno. 1670. Preaching and Publishing the Gospel of Peace: One Anne Watts a Woman Informer told the Officers, who came with a Warrant and had him before one Christopher Colthorp a Justice, who Fined him Twenty Pounds, which Warrant and Conviction was sent to the Justices in the Isle of Ely, Namely John Laney, Hen. Hitch, and Tho. March, who in pursuance of the said Norfolk Justices Conviction, sent their Warrants to the Officers of Little-port who distrained as much Houshold stuff and Timber, from the said Samuel, as was worth more than Twenty Pounds.

div.p:
Now thus far it was true, that Sam. was at that Meeting convicted, the conviction sent into the Isle of Ely, and also true, that he was distrained, as I above observ'd, but the
Goods distrained were never Sold, but return'd to him again, and consequently Sam. Cater no Sufferer. And yet there being but the colour of a Suffering, that he might not loose the glory of it, he presently got it Recorded in the Quarterly Book, as a Testimony of his Valour and notable Courage; shewing future Ages what the Quaker Teachers were; and that not only this Sir Christopher Colthorp, but the Justices, in the Isle of Ely, had a hand in this lamentable Tragedy; and that they must stand Recorded Persecutors to future Ages, &c. Now Reader, does not this look Formidable? Will not people that read this a hundred years hence, when this Holy Chronicle, and Compendious History comes out, look like a noble Suffering, a valiant Act, and deservedly Famous? But alas! alas! it was so far from a Suffering, that it was no Suffering at all, in that he had his Goods again; nay yet worse, for he had Ten Pounds sent him from London out of the Quakers Exchequer, Fund or Treasury, or what you will call it, by John Peacock late of St. Ives Draper, as an encouragement, doubtless, for him to clap his Hands and Heart on the poor Hearers, who tho they Suffer really, are not proportionably Rewarded to what the Preachers meet with; for I find in the same old Records; that Sam. Fulligg, Clem. Crabb, Tho. Hawkes, James Peachey, John Love, Hen. Waddelow. Rob. Crabb, for being at a Meeting the 9th. of June, 1670. Had as many Horses,
Cows, Mares, Pewter, and Brass, and other things taken, as was worth much more than Sam. had distrained, yet I never heard they had any thing sent them from the Bankers, and Purse-mongers at London. But this is not all yet, tho this be bad enough, and indeed a most horrible cheat put upon future Ages: To stand Recorded a Sufferer Twenty Pounds, when he Suffered not a Groat; nay, so far from that, that for his noble Act he had Ten Pounds sent him; so that he got Ten Pounds clear into the pocket. And tho I say this is a horrible cheat, and a Blot it will be on their Chronicle, and a blemish to their Pretences; yet I still say there is worse, at least an Aggravation of this Cheat: See a Book stiled, The Lamentable Cry of Oppression, &c. Put forth by Samuel Cater and Joseph Harrison, 9 Years after this crying Fine of 20 l. where in their Epistle to the Reader; they thus Write. Serious Reader, should we have set out all the matter and manner of Proceedings; it would have swel'd into too big a Volumn, and may make the Heathen to question the Christian Religion, and the Papists laugh, and p. 14. Here being a Meeting, at the House of Joseph Harrison, in Phakenham, the 2d, of the 5th. Month, 1670. And Samuel Cater being there, and declaring the Truth to the People present; William Watts's Wife came, and after some time went to inform the Officers thereof, who came and had Friends before Christopher Colthorp: Then Samuel appealed
to the Justice; the Justice answered, he would Fine Samuel 20 l. which accordingly he did, and sent the Records of Conviction to the Magistrates at Ely; who sent out their Warrants, and took away his Goods, &c. Thus far Sam. printed 1679.

Thus Reader you see that 9 Years after this Fine was levied, Sam. renews his complaint afresh, as if he had a mind to have Ten Pounds more, but not a word of his Goods being return'd, not a word of his Ten Pounds sent him from London. Well, his Norfolk Friends poor hearts, they thought doubtless that he had been a Twenty Pound Sufferer, but instead thereof a Ten Pound gainer; Oh monstrous! Are these the great Sufferers, who pretend, nay say plainly, that their Sufferings are greater than the Sufferings of Christ and his Apostles or Martyrs, as anon I shall shew? Well, but Sam. has not done yet, but in p. 44. And now it is upon me [saith Samuel] from the Lord to warn you all that have had any hand in oppressing his Children, and evil intreating his Servants and Messengers that he has sent amongst you, to exhort you to turn from the evil of your ways, and the violence that is in your Hands and Hearts; but instead of receiving them and their Testimony Viz. Sam. and his Testimony, the pretended great Sufferer. you have caused them to sufferBehold the impudence of this Man. and them that did receive them and their Testimony; the Lord give
you Repentance before it be too late, and you be cut off, is the desire of himYea, if you can get 10 l. clear by your suffering. that chuses rather to suffer Affliction with the People of God, than to live in the pleasures of this World. S. Cater.

Come G. Whitehead, I have not done with you yet; I have still more to say, why your Sufferings do not merit you the name of the Church of the First Born; though I have shewed enough, to be a great sign of the contrary. I must a little view some other Sufferings in this Book, before I leave this Head; you know your Prophet Burrows say, p. 273. That the Sufferings of the People of God (called Quakers) in this Age is a greater Suffering, and more unjust, then in the dayes of Christ or of the Apostles, or any time since. What was done to Christ and the Apostles was chiefly done by a Law, and in great part by the due execution of a Law, &c.

Come G. W. I will not now animadvert on the Blasphemy of this your Doctrine, nor yet wherein you justifie the Jews and Heathens in their Murdering the Lord of Life and Glory; and persecuting the holy Apostles and blessed Martyrs to Death, for his Name's sake, tho' for this piece of Blasphemy, as well as abundance more in it, the Book ought to be Burnt on Tower-hill, as a Testimony against your Blasphemous Tenets: No my work at this time shall be first to Collect some of the Sufferings in Samuel Cater's Book, which he says
will make the Heathen Question the Christian Religion, and the Papists laugh and the Heavens blush; it is Intituled, The Lamentable Cry of Oppression, represented to all moderate Men in Authority. And when I have Collected a Sample of these your Friends Sufferings; then I shall Collect some of the Apostles and Martyrs Sufferings, and leave the World to judge who are the greatest, which suffered the most, by or without a Law; and upon whom the Law was most duly Executed.

row.cell: Imprimis. William Monk, for meeting contrary to an Act of Parliament, made in the 22d, Year of K. Ch. II. had taken from him a Chair, Table, and 4 Joynt Stools worth
Another, a pair of dog Irons, a Hake, a Chafing-dish and a pair of Tongues,
Another, 3 yards and quarter of Scotch Cloath,
Another, a pair of old Curtains,
Another, a Flaggon,
